episodes.original_body:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

Date:10/18/2021			
User: jchumbley	
Note: "Defendant vehicle reported stolen 30 min prior to collision per PR. Driver fled scene on foot.
 
Client was passenger in Destiny Adkins vehicle. We rep Adkins for a 5/1/21 MVA.
 
No insurance listed for either vehicle on PR - CC results - no insurance found on PIP side. Allstate listed as BI vehicle. Client should qualify for KAC. 
 
Client has Passport
 
Treatment - EMS to UofL. ULP follow up- may be UofL Ortho
 
Injuries: Intake states client broke both ankles????
 
BI 0 Allstate - denied claim -copy of denial in route
 "
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

On October 18, 2021, notes by jchumbley document the following regarding the motor vehicle accident. The defendant vehicle was reported stolen 30 minutes prior to the collision per the police report, and the driver fled the scene on foot. The client was a passenger in Destiny Adkins’ vehicle. We have previously represented Destiny Adkins for a motor vehicle accident on May 1, 2021. No insurance was listed for either vehicle on the police report; CC results show no insurance found on the PIP side. Allstate is listed as the BI insurer. The client should qualify for the Kentucky Assigned Claims (KAC) program. The client has a passport. Treatment involved EMS transporting the client to UofL, and there is a ULP follow-up planned that may involve UofL Orthopedics. 

Injuries: Intake states the client broke both ankles????? BI 0; Allstate denied the claim, and a copy of the denial is in route.
episodes.author: Migrations+Iteam

about.relevance: no PIP insurance found on CC/police report

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. The client is Juanita Nicole Downs, whose motor vehicle accident occurred on April 16, 2021, and who is involved in Allstate Claim 0625854435 alongside Destiny Atkins.

In a February 3, 2022 email, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm addressed Patrice Gaines at Allstate about the Allstate claim involving Destiny Atkins and Juanita Downs. He stated that he had attached letters of representation for both Juanita and Destiny, a photo of Juanita’s ankle from after surgery, and a bill labeled as a UL bill along with one UL file. He noted that the UL file he attached contains her discharge summary and injuries. He also indicated that Juanita had fractured one ankle and dislocated the other, and he asked, “How much is the policy?” An image file named “Juanita Downs RIGHT ANKLE.jpg” was attached as part of the correspondence.

Allstate responded later that day, February 3, 2022 at 11:46 AM, with a message indicating that the file had been transferred to them for further handling. Patrice Gaines asked Aaron to forward a letter of representation and requested an update on the client’s injuries, treatment, and medical bills amount. The message was accompanied by Allstate’s confidentiality and privacy notices and referenced the unique Conversation ID FRdc7efdcd452944.

The email thread also contains an earlier exchange from January 4, 2022. In that exchange, Aaron Whaley told claims@claims.allstate.com, “Ashley, here is the report I mentioned. Let me know after you review it and speak to your insured.” Earlier that same day, Allstate, via Ashley Stuteville, replied to acknowledge the information and asked that Aaron send the information discussed so they could review it. The thread then includes Aaron’s signature listing Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky contact information.

In summary, the communications show an ongoing exchange regarding Allstate Claim 0625854435 for Juanita Downs (and Destiny Atkins), with January 2022 discussions about a report and requested materials, and a February 3, 2022 exchange where Aaron provided representation letters, medical attachments including a post-surgery ankle injury photo and UL-related documents, and Allstate’s request for representation documentation and an updated summary of injuries, treatments, and medical bills, along with policy amount inquiry.
episodes.author: Aaron Whaley

Litigation Review: Def reported vehicle stolen after police located the vehicle and MVA report was filed - Vehicle stolen from 4408 Clarene Drive which is now Def new address - Address on Police Report no longer valid - Def lives with 5 other people including Demetrius Earl Turner DOB 04/02/1987 DLN T11162635 who is her age - assumption he is significant other - Ran Def SO through CourtNet - Def SO was cited on 02/21/2021 driving the listed vehicle with cancelled tags & suspended license - Jefferson 21-T-007313 - Def SO appeared in Court the day prior to the accident and provided verification of New Tags & Title Transfer
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on April 16, 2021 with Juanita Nicole Downs regarding a motor vehicle accident. The litigation review notes that the defendant reported the vehicle stolen after police located the vehicle and an MVA report was filed. The vehicle was stolen from 4408 Clarene Drive, which is the defendant’s new address, and the address listed on the police report is no longer valid.

The defendant lives with five other people, including Demetrius Earl Turner, born 04/02/1987, DLN T11162635, who is her age; it is assumed he is her significant other. A search of the defendant’s significant other through CourtNet shows that Turner was cited on 02/21/2021 for driving the listed vehicle with cancelled tags and a suspended license in Jefferson case 21-T-007313. Turner appeared in court the day prior to the accident and provided verification of new tags and a title transfer.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

The parties and counsel in the July 2022 email exchange include Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, and Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with CCs to A. Campbell Ewen and Beth Alexander. The July 14, 2022 communication was sent from Stempien to Tuttle and Whaley, copied to the two additional names, and signed with full firm contact details and a standard attorney-privileged disclaimer.

In a June 30, 2022 email, Sarena M. Tuttle acknowledged service matters and noted that the firm is open to settlement discussions at any time. The email also provided the law firm’s contact information and new email address for Ms. Tuttle.

In a subsequent reply dated July 14, 2022, Mr. Stempien addressed three points. Third, he asked whether there is an intention to amend the Complaint, suggesting that they might wait to see what happens when any amended pleading is served on Ms. Nail. The email closed with Mr. Stempien’s contact information and the firm’s standard disclaimer regarding privileged communications, no attorney-client relationship, and tax-related disclosures under Circular 230.

Overall, the exchange records a dispute over service validity (with reference to a Courtnet return noting the term “COVID”), a potential extension of time to answer through August 1, and questions about possibly amending the Complaint, all within the procedural posture of Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate as of mid-July 2022. In the matter of Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate, the note concerns a motor vehicle collision that occurred on April 16, 2021, involving Juanita Nicole Downs. The client for this matter is Juanita Nicole Downs. The Whaley Law Firm represents the plaintiffs, including Adkins and Downs, while the defendants are Stephanie Nail and Allstate, with Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC representing Nail and Allstate. The correspondence centers on service issues, potential extensions, and the possibility of amending the Complaint in CourtNet, with communications exchanged between the two firms and related counsel.

On June 30, 2022, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent a message to Brian Stempien (and copied A. Campbell Ewen and Aaron Whaley) regarding representation and settlement discussions. Tuttle thanked Stempien for his letter dated June 28, 2022, noting that Nail was being represented at Allstate’s request and that settlement discussions were welcome at any point if an offer could be made. She stated that, per CourtNet, Nail was served via Certified Mail on June 15, 2022, and that they looked forward to receiving Nail’s Answer on or about July 15, 2022. Tuttle attached the Interrogatories propounded on Nail along with the Complaint served on June 15, 2022, and invited further discussion if settlement needed to be pursued or if additional information was required.

On July 14, 2022 at 10:50 a.m., Brian Stempien replied to Aaron Whaley and Ms. Tuttle. He noted that the return attached to the Courtnet electronic file uses the word “COVID” spelled out, and he stated that, in his view, this did not constitute effective service. He asked to be informed if Whaley’s side disagreed or intended to file a motion for default. Stempien also referenced the earlier discussion about a 30-day extension of the time to Answer by agreement and asked whether the parties were opposed to extending the deadline through August 1. He also inquired whether there was an intention to move to amend the Complaint and suggested that they might wait to see what happens when service is attempted on Ms. Nail. The note ended with Stempien’s signature block and contact information, including his office address, telephone and fax numbers, email, and website, along with standard attorney-privilege disclaimers typical of such correspondence.

Shortly thereafter, at 11:02 a.m. on the same day, July 14, 2022, Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm responded. He stated that he had no objection to extending the deadline to August 1. He added that if Allstate were to extend coverage, he would have no objection to an indefinite extension while he attempted to resolve the claim with Allstate. This response indicated openness to a longer extension if necessary to pursue a resolution with Allstate. The email also carried the customary firm disclaimers, tax-related notices, and attorney-client privilege language typical of the correspondence in this matter.

In summary, the proximate issues discussed in these communications concerned the validity of Nail’s service, the potential extension of time to answer through August 1 (with openness to further extensions if Allstate extended coverage), whether to amend the Complaint, and ongoing settlement discussions or resolutions related to the Adkins & Downs v. Nail & Allstate case arising from the April 16, 2021 motor vehicle incident involving Juanita Nicole Downs.

Recvd DC Stempien Request for Extension to Answer Complaint as well - Their position is service is not effective service - Requested Notice of Intent to File Default if we decide too - Also asked if we intended to Amend Complaint - If so "perhaps we should just wait to see what happens when you try to serve that on Ms. Nail." - AW Granted extension to August 1st - Advised he would grant indefinite extension should Allstate extend coverage in order to resolve claim w/Allstate #Lit #Extension
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on April 16, 2021 with Juanita Nicole Downs regarding a motor vehicle accident.

We received from defense counsel Stempien a request for an extension to answer the complaint, with their position that service was not effective. They requested a Notice of Intent to File Default if we decide to proceed and asked whether we intended to amend the complaint; if so, “perhaps we should just wait to see what happens when you try to serve that on Ms. Nail.” Attorney AW granted the extension to August 1. He advised he would grant an indefinite extension should Allstate extend coverage in order to resolve the claim with Allstate. #Lit #Extension
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita Nicole Downs MVA case, filed for a motor vehicle accident that occurred on April 16, 2021. The client is Juanita Nicole Downs.

In the Re: Claim correspondence, on October 25, 2022 at 1:25 PM, Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Juanita Downs at juanitadowns98@gmail.com and to Sarena Tuttle at sarena@whaleylawfirm.com, with a copy to JuanitaNicoleDownsMVAZ954678@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. He reported that service had finally been effected on the defendant and that the insurance company had filed an answer. He also stated that discovery would be sent soon to answer and that Sarena would work with the client on that process.

Earlier that same day, at 11:14 AM, Juanita Downs wrote: “Hello I was reaching out in regards to my suit and the process of it if you can get back with me at your earliest convenience I would greatly appreciate it.” The message was sent from her iPhone.

Looking back to prior messages in July 2022, on July 19, 2022 at 1:03 PM, Juanita Downs asked: “Alright how is everything looking so far?” This message was also sent from her iPhone.

On July 18, 2022, a series of exchanges occurred. At 2:53 PM, Aaron Whaley wrote: “No, you do not.” In response, at 2:51 PM, Juanita Downs asked: “Do I need to make an appearance at court anytime?” Aaron Whaley replied at 2:49 PM: “IT has been filed and I am fighting in Court.” Earlier, at 2:31 PM on the same day, Juanita wrote: “Hey my name is Juanita Downs I was wondering if there’s any progress being made in my case that had to be taken to court I haven’t heard from anyone I’m probably a month or 2.” The exchanges continued through these timestamps, with signatures from Aaron Whaley and the Whaley Law Firm listed at the end of the messages, including the firm’s address and phone number.

The correspondence reflects ongoing litigation activity: service of the defendant completed, the insurer’s answer filed, and forthcoming discovery with Sarena Tuttle assisting the client. The record also shows repeated client inquiries about case progress and court appearances, and interim attorney updates indicating the case has been filed and is being fought in court. The communication concludes with the standard firm signature block for Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, 502-583-4022.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

In November 2022, in relation to a discovery request meeting for Juanita Downs’s motor vehicle accident matter, contact was exchanged between Juanita and The Whaley Law Firm regarding scheduling. The matter’s subject was “Re: Your Discovery Request Meeting.”

On November 11, 2022, at 1:10 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle wrote to Juanita Downs: “Good afternoon Juanita, Aaron sent me your request to schedule a time to come in and go over your Discovery Responses. Unfortunately, Wednesday is not available, we could do any other day next week. Please feel free to give us a call and set up a time that works for you.” The signature block identified Sarena Tuttle and The Whaley Law Firm, including the firm’s address, phone numbers, and email address, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Later that same day, at 1:35 PM, Juanita Downs replied: “I can do any day before 1pm I’m only off Wednesday and Saturday next week.” The message was sent from her iPhone.

At 2:55 PM on November 11, 2022, Sarena responded with a proposed appointment time: “Let’s do Thursday at 10am. This should not take more than 30 minutes to an hour at best.” This message again came from Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, whose contact details followed in the signature, including the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, the direct line and main office line, extension 104, and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to please use the new email address.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

On January 16, 2023, a forwarding email was sent in the matter titled Downs and Adkins v. Nail, et al. from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle and to Juanita Nicole Downs (identified as MVA 4/16/2021). The subject line of the forwarded message was the case name. In the body of the email, Aaron asked, “Where are we on getting answers? I know client has been in touch.” This message was itself a forward of prior correspondence.

The forwarded content included a January 16, 2023, 5:25 PM message from Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC. In that message, Stempien wrote that he was still working on discovery and was under pressure to file a motion if the client’s responses were not received soon. He proposed deposition dates for the clients on January 24, January 25, January 30, or February 3, and he signed with the firm’s name and contact information: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243. His office phone was (502) 245-7474, fax (502) 245-7025, toll-free (866) 431-3599, and his email was bstempien@thattorneys.com. He also provided the firm’s website, http://www.thslaw.co. The message included the customary Privileged and Confidential disclaimer, noting that the information was attorney-privileged and confidential, intended for the named recipient, and that dissemination or copying was prohibited if the reader was not the intended recipient. It also carried a “No Attorney-Client Relationship” disclaimer, stating that sending or receiving email did not establish an attorney-client relationship, and it repeated the IRS Circular 230 tax-advice notices applicable to tax communications.

Within the same forwarded thread, there is an earlier message dated Friday, December 23, 2022, from Brian Stempien to Aaron Whaley, with Beth Alexander and A. Campbell Ewen CC’d, subject “Downs and Adkins v. Nail, et al.” In that December 23 message, Stempien extended Christmas wishes and explained that they were still working on responses to discovery that had been sent to Ms. Nail along with the Complaint. He noted that he expected the discovery responses from their side within the next few weeks. He also requested that Aaron have his office work with Beth to get the depositions of their clients on the books, ideally in January. He invited questions and wished Aaron and his family a great Christmas. The closing included Brian D. Stempien’s name and the same firm contact details as above, followed again by the Privileged and Confidential disclaimer and the No Attorney-Client Relationship disclaimer, as well as the IRS Circular 230 tax-advice warning. The December 23 message was part of the same email thread and included Brian’s signature block listing the firm’s address in Middletown, Louisville, KY, the same office phone and fax numbers, toll-free number, and email bstempien@thattorneys.com, along with the website and the standard disclaimers.

The December 23, 2022 message was preceded by the “From: Brian Stempien, Sent: Friday, December 23, 2022 1:15 PM” header and included the full content described above. It was followed by the standard firm disclaimers, and the message also contained the sender’s and recipient’s email addresses and the firm’s physical address as noted. The content within this chain repeatedly references discovery responses, the Ms. Nail discovery, and scheduling depositions for January, alongside the ongoing discovery work and the expectation of client responses.

In summary, the communication record shows ongoing discovery work and scheduling discussions for the Downs and Adkins v. Nail matter, with Juanita Nicole Downs as the client, connected to a motor vehicle accident case from 4/16/2021. The timeline includes a December 23, 2022 email urging production of discovery responses and deposition scheduling, and a January 16, 2023 email indicating continued efforts on discovery and proposing deposition dates (January 24, 25, 30, or February 3), all within an email thread that carries the standard attorney-privilege notices, no attorney-client relationship disclaimers, and tax-related Circular 230 notices.

The narrative begins with the first outreach: on February 18, 2023, at 9:59 PM, Juanita Downs sent an email from her iPhone to request an update on her case, stating, “I’m reaching out to get an update on my case.”

On February 20, 2023, at 10:51 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Juanita. The message opened with a greeting: “Good morning Juanita,” and explained that the case was still in the written discovery phase, a stage the parties had previously discussed. Sarena noted that once the case moves into the oral discovery phase, the firm would reach out to discuss the best dates and times for the Defense Attorney to take Juanita’s deposition. She invited Juanita to contact the firm with any additional questions to discuss them in further detail. Sarena’s signature block provided her title, the firm’s name and address (The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), and contact information: Direct line 502-357-9971, Office line 502-583-4022 ext 104, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with a note indicating a new email address. The email also shows that Aaron Whaley was CC’d at agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

Later that same day, at 1:48 PM, Juanita sent another email to Sarena with the subject Re: Update, asking, “Do you know how long it will take.” This message was sent from Juanita Downs, addressed to Sarena Tuttle, and CC’d Aaron Whaley. The message was dated Monday, February 20, 2023, at 13:48:02 -0500, and it carried the standard “Sent from my iPhone” signature.

__Re: Settlement__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Juanita Downs [juanitadowns98@gmail.com](mailto:juanitadowns98@gmail.com)
CC: 
Date: Thu, 30 Mar 2023 15:29:59 -0400

Good afternoon Juanita,
 Thank you for reaching out. Your claim is in litigation which is a
lengthy process averaging 18-24 months without any extensions or delays. At
this time your claim is in the Discovery Phase which is the longest of
phases. During this phase the attorney's exchange official documents that
require certification from their sources as well as other information
related to the accident, injuries & treatment.
 Once we move out of the written discovery phase, we will enter an
oral discovery phase at which time, we will look to schedule depositions of
the defendants and any experts needed for your claim. If the Defense
Attorney would like to take your oral statement, we will reach out to you
about scheduling.
 Please understand that there are a lot of things that take place on
your behalf without your direct participation. In the meantime, we are
working on your behalf and will reach out once we move into the oral
discovery phase of your claim. However, if you have any questions, please
feel free to contact us to discuss them in further detail.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

> Hello I’m reaching out because I haven’t heard anything in months about my

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

On March 30, 2023, a message dated 3:29 PM -0400 was sent from Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm to Juanita Downs regarding settlement of her motor vehicle accident claim. The email begins with a greeting and thanks for her outreach. It explains that Juanita’s claim is in litigation, which is described as a lengthy process averaging 18–24 months without extensions or delays. The claim is currently in the Discovery Phase, noted as the longest phase of the process. During this phase, the attorneys exchange official documents that require certification from their sources, as well as other information related to the accident, injuries, and treatment.

The email states that once the written discovery phase is completed, the case will enter an oral discovery phase, at which time depositions of the defendants and any needed experts will be scheduled. If the Defense Attorney would like to take Juanita’s oral statement, the firm will reach out to schedule it. The message emphasizes that many tasks take place on Juanita’s behalf without her direct participation, and that the firm is working on her behalf and will reach out once the case moves into the oral discovery phase. Juanita is invited to contact the firm with any questions to discuss them in more detail.

The communication is signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, identified as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Contact details listed include D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is her new email address.

Earlier on the same day, Thursday, March 30, 2023, at about 3:23 PM, Juanita Downs wrote: “Hello I’m reaching out because I haven’t heard anything in months about my case,” noting the message was sent from her iPhone.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. The following notes document a chain of attorney communications related to the matter Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate, which is occurring alongside the underlying motor vehicle accident (MVA) case from April 16, 2021.

On April 21, 2023, a forward was sent from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm to Sarena Tuttle regarding Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate. The subject line of the forwarded message was “Fwd: Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate.” In the forwarded content, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC wrote that his carrier was pressing him to file a motion to compel and asked for updates on deposition dates and discovery. The message included the law firm’s contact information: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, in the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, with office phone (502) 245-7474, fax (502) 245-7025, toll-free (866) 431-3599, and email bstempien@thattorneys.com. The firm’s website was listed as http://www.thslaw.co. The message contained standard privileged and confidential notices asserting attorney-client privilege, stating that the information was intended for the named recipient and that dissemination or copying if received in error was prohibited, along with notices about no attorney-client relationship and related IRS Circular 230 tax disclosures.

The chain then included earlier correspondence. In a message from Brian Stempien to Aaron Whaley (dated April 21, 2023, around 2:09 PM), Stempien reiterated that his carrier was pushing for a motion to compel and requested information on deposition dates and discovery. This message was accompanied by the same firm signature block and confidentiality notices.

Earlier in the thread, in a March 22, 2023 email from Aaron Whaley to Brian Stempien, Whaley stated that they were working on completing the discovery responses and noted a “little confusion” between himself and Sarena Tuttle. He mentioned that he had assigned Sarena Tuttle a task to redo service due to a prior objection raised by Stempien.

Prior to that, on March 21, 2023 (the email dated around 5:02 PM), Brian Stempien wrote explaining his questions about when they could expect the client’s discovery responses and dates for the deposition. He also noted that there had been a peculiar filing of the complaint again in the case and asked whether this was intentional or if there was anything else missing. He emphasized that they were working to close the loop on Ms. Nail’s discovery and that obtaining the client’s responses and her deposition should be the first priority.

The chain includes earlier correspondence from July 14, 2022. In a message from Aaron Whaley dated July 14, 2022 at 11:03 AM, Whaley indicated that he did not object to an extension to August 1, and that if Allstate extended coverage, he would not object to an indefinite extension while attempting to resolve the claim with Allstate. This message was sent to Brian Stempien, with Sarena Tuttle copied, and also included A. Campbell Ewen (ACEwen@ewenandkinney.com) and Beth Alexander. The subject line was “Re: Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate,” and the message carried the standard privileged and confidential notices.

Earlier still, on July 14, 2022, at 10:50 AM, Brian Stempien had written a request to Aaron and Ms. Tuttle. He noted an issue with service, explaining that the return attached to the Courtnet electronic file spelled out as “COVID,” which he stated did not constitute effective service, and he asked to be advised if they disagreed or intended to file a motion for default. He also reminded that there had been a discussion about a 30-day extension of the time to answer by agreement, and asked to know whether there was opposition to extending through August 1. Finally, he asked whether there was an intention to move to amend the Complaint, suggesting they wait to see what happens when attempting to serve that on Ms. Nail. The message included the same firm details and legal/disclaimer notices as above.

Overall, the record shows a back-and-forth concerning discovery responses, deposition dates, service issues, potential amendments to the Complaint, and extensions of deadlines, across communications dated July 2022 through April 2023. The communications involved Aaron Whaley (Whaley Law Firm), Sarena Tuttle, Brian D. Stempien (Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC), Beth Alexander, and A. Campbell Ewen, among others, and were governed by standard attorney-client privilege notices, confidentiality declarations, and related IRS Circular 230 disclosures. The case at hand remains the Adkins & Downs v. Stephanie Nail & Allstate matter, connected to the underlying MVA case from April 16, 2021, with the client identified as Juanita Nicole Downs.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita Nicole Downs MVA, filed 4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

In the matter of Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, communications between the Whaley Law Firm and Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC trace the ongoing discovery and deposition scheduling discussions. The most recent thread begins with an email dated April 24, 2023, in which Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm apologizes for a delay and attaches the Plaintiff’s Responses to the opposing party’s discovery requests. She notes that the Plaintiff’s Responses are attached and asks whether counsel and their client are available for depositions on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, and indicates that deposition format can be via Zoom or at the opposing counsel’s office. The attachments listed in that email are three documents dated 2023-04-18: “Adkins & Downs NOS Resp to DC Disc R...,” “Adkins Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf,” and “Downs Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf.”

The email chain shows a longer history of discovery and scheduling communications beginning in 2022 and continuing into 2023. On July 14, 2022, Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley discussed extending deadlines, with Aaron indicating no objection to extending the time to August 1 if Allstate would also extend, while noting issues with service and a related discussion about whether a 30-day extension of the time to answer had been agreed. Brian had raised concerns about service in that period, including references to a Courtnet filing that spelled out the word “COVID,” and he noted the possibility of seeking an extension by agreement.

Earlier, on March 21, 2023, Brian asked Aaron when he could expect the client’s discovery responses and dates for the depositions, and he commented on a “peculiar filing of the complaint again today” in the case. He stated that they were working to close the loop on Ms. Nail’s discovery but that obtaining the client’s responses and her deposition on the books should be their first priority. The following day, March 22, 2023, Aaron Whaley replied that they were working on finishing the responses and mentioned a minor disagreement between himself and Sarena Tuttle, noting that he had assigned Sarena a task to redo service due to a prior objection.

Then, on April 21, 2023, a forwarded message from Brian Stempien indicates that his carrier is pressing him to file a motion to compel and asks for confirmation of deposition dates and discovery, reinforcing that the parties were actively moving toward depositions and discovery scrutiny. Finally, on April 24, 2023, Sarena Tuttle responded with an apology for the delay and provided the Plaintiff’s Discovery responses, along with proposed deposition dates (May 23, 25, 30, or June 1) and the option to conduct them via Zoom or in the opposing counsel’s office. The email also includes standard attorney-privilege and confidentiality notices along with “No Attorney-Client Relationship” disclaimers and a Circular 230 tax disclosure warning typical of the firm’s communications.

Throughout these exchanges, the subject matter remained the Adkins & Downs v. Nail & Allstate case, the Plaintiffs’ discovery responses, and scheduling for depositions, with multiple attachments and several rounds of communications between the Whaley Law Firm and Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC. The note also preserves the presence of the Whaley firm’s contacts and standard disclaimer language typical of their emails.

Case: Juanita Nicole Downs, a motor vehicle accident matter from 4-16-2021, concerns Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate. The client in this file is Juanita Nicole Downs. The communications summarized below concern scheduling depositions, responding to discovery, and related procedural matters in the Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate case, with participants including Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC; Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal at The Whaley Law Firm; Aaron Whaley of The Whaley Law Firm; and Beth Alexander of Stempien’s firm. The emails contain standard attorney-privileged and confidential disclosures, disclaimers about no attorney-client relationship, and an IRS Circular 230 warning regarding tax advice, all of which are repeatedly included in the message bodies.

On June 2, 2023, Brian D. Stempien sent an email to Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle, with Beth Alexander and others cc’d, proposing that depositions of the parties be set in June if possible and asking Sarena to contact Beth regarding dates. He added to Aaron, asking him to call when he had a moment. The message bore Stempien’s firm contact information and included the firm’s standard privilege disclaimer and related notices.

Earlier in the chain, on April 24, 2023, Sarena Tuttle replied to Brian Stempien, apologizing for a delay and noting that the Plaintiff’s responses to the discovery requests were attached. She indicated that their deposition dates were flexible and asked whether Brian and his client were available on May 23, May 25, May 30, or June 1, offering the deposition options either via Zoom or at Brian’s office. The email also listed attached documents: several files titled 2023.04.18 Adkins & Downs NOS Resp to DC Disc R..., 2023.04.18 Adkins Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf, and 2023.04.18 Downs Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf, along with references to image placeholders. Tuttle signed with her name and provided her contact information, noting a new email address.

The chain also contains a forwarded message from April 21, 2023. In this message, Brian Stempien wrote to Aaron Whaley that his carrier was pushing him to file a motion to compel and requested information about deposition dates and discovery would be forthcoming. He provided his firm’s contact details and attached the customary privilege and confidentiality notices.

In a prior exchange, dated March 22, 2023, Aaron Whaley replied to Brian Stempien, explaining that they were working on completing the discovery responses and noting a little confusion between Aaron and Sarena. Aaron mentioned that he had asked Sarena to redo service due to a prior objection.

On March 21, 2023, Brian Stempien had sent a message to Aaron Whaley inquiring when the client’s discovery responses and deposition dates could be expected. He also mentioned receiving a peculiar filing of the complaint again that day and asked whether it was intentional or if something was missing. He stated that they were trying to close the loop on Stephanie Nail’s discovery but that obtaining the client’s responses and her deposition on the books was their first priority. This message also carried the standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

Throughout these exchanges, the messages consistently reference the Adkins & Downs v Nail & Allstate case, with depositions being scheduled and discovery responses being prepared or awaited. The communication threads reveal a focus on setting June deposition dates (and May options) and on advancing discovery in tandem with negotiations and motions such as a potential motion to compel, as indicated by Brian Stempien’s April 21, 2023 note. The attachments referenced in the April 24, 2023 email indicate that Plaintiff’s discovery responses were provided for review, and the conversation includes the routine disclaimers about privilege, confidentiality, and the non-establishment of an attorney-client relationship.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. The client is Juanita Nicole Downs, whose motor vehicle accident occurred on April 16, 2021, and the matter captioned Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate is being pursued.

On June 6, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Beth Alexander with Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley copied. In the message, she stated that their office was available for depositions on June 20, 22, 27, or 29, and that they would like to take Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day, anticipating that the depositions of all three parties would require a full day. The email included Sarena’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address.

Earlier in the thread, on June 2, 2023, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, wrote to Aaron Whaley and Sarena, requesting that the depositions of their clients be scheduled in June if possible and asking them to contact Beth Alexander regarding available dates. Brian provided his firm’s contact details: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; office 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025; toll-free 1-866-431-3599; email bstempien@thattorneys.com; website www.thslaw.co. The message included the standard attorney-privilege and confidentiality disclaimer, noted that no attorney-client relationship is created by sending or receiving the email, and carried the IRS/Circular 230 warning about tax-related disclosures.

The June 2 message sits within a longer email chain that includes earlier exchanges. In a June 2 reply, the recipients were asked to coordinate deposition dates with Beth and to advance scheduling. The thread also contains a forwarded excerpt from Brian’s June 2 message showing that he had asked Aaron and Sarena to set depositions in June and to contact Beth regarding dates.

In the prior portion of the thread, on April 24, 2023, Sarena Tuttle responded to Brian Stempien, apologizing for delays and noting that Plaintiff’s Discovery Responses were attached. She asked whether he and his client were available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, and stated that depositions could be conducted either via Zoom or in Beth Alexander’s office. Her signature again listed her role and contact details at The Whaley Law Firm, including the newly noted email address, and the message referenced attachments labeled as NOS Resp to DC Disc R and Final PDFs for Adkins Resp to Disc Req and Downs Resp to Disc Req.

Earlier still, on April 21, 2023, Aaron Whaley replied to Brian, explaining that they were working on finishing the discovery responses and noting a bit of confusion between Aaron and Sarena, mentioning that he had asked Sarena to redo a service after a prior objection. This followed Brian Stempien’s earlier inquiry on April 21, 2023, 2:09 PM, asking when his colleague could expect the client’s discovery response and indicating pressure from his carrier to file a motion to compel. Brian’s contact details and firm information were included in that message as well, along with the standard confidentiality and privilege warnings.

Finally, in a prior exchange from March 21, 2023, Brian Stempien had asked Aaron Whaley when the discovery responses could be expected. Aaron replied on March 22, 2023, indicating that they were working on finishing the responses and noting a small amount of confusion with Sarena, mentioning that he had tasked Sarena with redoing service due to a prior objection.

In summary, the case notes reflect a string of communications among the parties and counsel regarding scheduling depositions (notably seeking to depose Mrs. Nail on the same day as the other depositions, potentially occupying a full day for all three), as well as ongoing discovery responses and related administrative matters, with multiple dates proposed across April, May, and June 2023 and standard confidentiality and privilege language interspersed throughout the correspondence.

This case note concerns Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, in connection with a motor vehicle accident case involving Juanita Nicole Downs (file name: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021; client: Juanita Nicole Downs). The notes trace the ongoing discussion about scheduling depositions in June 2023 and the related discovery materials.

The earliest referenced thread in this note is an email chain starting April 21, 2023. In that message, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, writing to Aaron Whaley and with Sarena Tuttle copied, indicates that his carrier is pressuring him to file a motion to compel. He asks to be informed about deposition dates and discovery, and asks that the recipients let him know about the available deposition dates and discovery timeline.

On April 24, 2023, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Brian, apologizing for the delay. She states that the plaintiff’s responses to discovery are attached and asks whether Brian and his client are available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, with the option to conduct depositions via Zoom or in Brian’s office. She notes that attachments include the plaintiff’s discovery responses, specifically files named 2023.04.18 Adkins NOS Resp to DC Disc R..., 2023.04.18 Adkins Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf, and 2023.04.18 Downs Resp to Disc Req - Final.pdf. This message also contains Sarena’s standard signature block, including her contact information and a reminder that the email is sent with confidentiality and privilege notices.

Earlier in the chain, on June 2, 2023, Brian Stempien sent a message to Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle asking to set the depositions of their clients in June if possible and requesting that Beth Alexander be contacted regarding dates. He also asked Aaron to call him when he had a moment.

On June 6, 2023, Sarena Tuttle replied to Beth Alexander and Brian, indicating that her office has availability for depositions on June 20, June 22, June 27, or June 29, and that they would like to take Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day, anticipating that all three depositions would require a full day. This message includes Sarena’s standard contact details and confidentiality notice.

Later on June 6, 2023, Beth Alexander, the paralegal to Brian Stempien, replied to Sarena. Beth notes that June 29 appears to be the only date among the proposed options on which Brian is available for two depositions; she states that Brian will not agree to conduct three depositions in one day. She asks whether Sarena can propose dates for the following week to schedule Ms. Nail’s deposition at their office. Beth provides her full professional contact information and includes a standard Privileged and Confidential disclaimer, a No Attorney-Client Relationship statement, and IRS Circular 230 disclosures about tax-related communications. The message also references an image attachment (cid:image001.jpg@01D99870.4AD19AB0).

Throughout these communications, standard disclaimers accompany each message. They note that the communications are attorney-privileged and confidential, intended only for the named recipient, and that any dissemination or copying by unintended recipients is prohibited. They also reiterate that sending or receiving email does not establish an attorney-client relationship, and they include the usual IRS Circular 230 warnings when tax advice is involved.

In summary, the notes document a coordinated effort among counsel to schedule depositions for Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate during June 2023, with a preference from The Whaley Law Firm to have Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day as the others (anticipating a full day for all three depositions) but with Brian Stempien indicating that three depositions in a single day would not be acceptable. The correspondence also reflects ongoing discovery activity from April 2023, including plaintiff discovery responses and the related scheduling discussions. The communications include multiple attachments and standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

Re: Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate

The following narrative summarizes the email communications in June 2023 between the attorneys and staff handling the Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate matter, in which Juanita Nicole Downs is the client. The Whaley Law Firm represents the plaintiffs, and contact details for the key participants are included where cited.

On June 6, 2023, at 12:23 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note: new email address) sent an email to Beth Alexander (Paralegal to Brian Stempien, Travis Herbert & Stempien, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, KY 40243; Ph: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025) and cc’d Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley. In her message, Sarena acknowledged that “3 is a lot in a day” for depositions and suggested scheduling options around the upcoming Fourth of July week: the following week could accommodate the 6th, or the week after that offered the 11th or 12th. She also provided her contact details and reiterated her new email address.

Earlier that same day, at 12:09 PM, Beth Alexander replied. She noted that June 29 is the only date among the proposed options when Brian is available for two depositions, and that Brian will not agree to three depositions in a single day. Beth asked if Sarena could propose dates for the following week so that Ms. Nail’s deposition could be set at their office. Beth’s signature followed, including her role as Paralegal to Brian Stempien and her firm information, along with standard privileged/Confidentiality notices and the usual attorney disclaimer language.

In a prior email thread dated June 6, 2023 at 10:51 AM, Sarena sent a message to Beth (cc’ing Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley) stating that their office was available for depositions on June 20, 22, 27, or 29. The plan was to take Mrs. Nail’s deposition on the same day as the other depositions, with the expectation that it would take a full day to complete all three depositions. Sarena again included her contact details and noted her new email address.

This June 6 exchange followed earlier correspondence. On June 2, 2023, Brian Stempien wrote to Aaron and Sarena, asking them to try to set the plaintiffs’ depositions in June if possible and to contact Beth regarding dates. He also requested that Aaron give him a call on the matter. Brian’s message was signed with his Travis Herbert & Stempien contact information and included the firm’s standard privilege and confidentiality disclaimer.

Additionally, on April 24, 2023 at 11:36 AM, Sarena sent an earlier note to Brian Stempien (cc: Aaron Whaley) apologizing for delays and attaching the Plaintiffs’ Responses to Defendants’ Discovery Requests. She indicated the depositions were flexible and asked whether Brian and his client were available on May 23, 25, 30, or June 1, with the option to conduct the depositions either via Zoom or in Brian’s office. She referenced attached documents (NOS Resp to DC Disc Req; Adkins Resp to Disc Req – Final; Downs Resp to Disc Req – Final) though the images themselves appear as embedded attachments in the email thread. As with the subsequent messages, Sarena closed with her Whaley Law Firm contact details and noted the new email address, alongside the standard Privileged and Confidential notices.

In addition to the substantive content, the emails consistently included the firm’s standard disclaimers: Privileged and Confidential; No Attorney-Client Relationship; instructions not to disseminate or copy if the recipient was not the intended one; and, where applicable, a Tax Regulations (Circular 230) warning about the reliability of any tax-related advice contained in the message.

Overall, the thread documents coordinated scheduling efforts for depositions in Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, with proposed June dates (20, 22, 27, or 29) and a plan to depose Mrs. Nail on the same day as the other two depositions, resulting in a full day for the three depositions. The parties exchanged availability and constraints (notably Brian’s limit of two depositions per day and his preference against three in one day) and iterated potential dates around the June calendar and the upcoming holiday week.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. The packet documents correspondence related to the matter Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, consisting of a chain of emails between Beth A. Alexander, paralegal to Brian Stempien at Travis Herbert & Stempien, and Sarena M. Tuttle, litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm.

The central topic across the emails is a deposition of Mrs. Nail in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail & Allstate matter, with the deposition notice setting July 12, 2023 at 2:00 PM to be held at the recipient’s office, as agreed. The parties discussed whether the deposition would be conducted in person or via Zoom, with the Whaley Law Firm indicating a preference for Zoom but a willingness to proceed at the other firm’s office.

The chronology begins on June 6, 2023. At 12:39 PM, Sarena wrote to Beth, “Awesome. Thank you as well. I will get our notice over to you as soon as possible.” At 12:40 PM, Beth asked, “Plaintiff’s depos at your office or ours?” At 12:42 PM, Sarena replied, “We prefer Zoom, but we can do your office.” Beth responded at 12:43 PM, “Great….thanks.” Later that same day, at 1:39 PM, Sarena sent the formal deposition notice: “Here is our Notice to Take Deposition of Mrs. Nail on July 12, 2023 starting at 2:00p in your office as agreed.” The exchange closes with the confirming note from Sarena reiterated in the message of June 6, 2023.

On June 6, 2023 at 12:39 PM (in a corresponding thread), Beth again acknowledged and referenced the notice process with the same party’s contact details in her signature. The communications include standard confidentiality and privilege notices common to attorney communications, stating that the messages are attorney-privileged and confidential and that there is no attorney‑client relationship established by sending or receiving the e-mails. Each message also contains the IRS Circular 230 warning regarding tax advice, noting that the sender is complying with regulatory requirements and that the document may not contain all required disclosures.

A subsequent development occurred on July 11, 2023. At 15:43:37 UTC, Beth emailed Sarena to report that they had been unable to reach Ms. Nail to confirm the deposition for tomorrow and that Brian is confident she will not appear; they had not been able to locate Ms. Nail since their initial conversation. Beth added that if her status changes, she would inform Sarena.

In summary, the depositions were planned for July 12, 2023 at 2:00 PM at the recipient’s office, with Zoom as a preferred option though in-person deposition at the office was acceptable. The communications reveal attempts to locate Ms. Nail and to confirm her attendance, with a firm belief by counsel that she may not attend. The emails include the standard privileged/confidential notices and the Circular 230 tax disclosures typical of this law firm correspondence.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This note pertains to the matter Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate.

On June 6, 2023, The Whaley Law Firm sent a Notice to Take Deposition of Mrs. Nail (Stephanie Nail) for July 12, 2023, starting at 2:00 p.m., to be held in the recipient’s office as agreed. The notice was from Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct lines were D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to please use the new email address. The message also included the standard practice signatures and notices typical of attorney communications, indicating Privileged and Confidential information, No Attorney-Client Relationship, and various disclaimers about inadvertent receipt, as well as a Circular 230 warning related to tax communications.

In the email thread, Beth A. Alexander, Paralegal to Brian Stempien at Travis Herbert & Stempien, responded from Louisville, KY, indicating that the plaintiff’s deposition could be held at either party’s office. The thread shows prior exchange noting a preference for Zoom, but the offices could accommodate if needed. Beth’s location details included the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, KY 40243, with contact numbers Ph: (502) 245-7474 and Fax: (502) 245-7025. The earlier messages also carried the standard Privileged and Confidential notices and the No Attorney-Client Relationship disclaimer, as well as the IRS Circular 230 warning about tax advice.

Sarena’s June 6, 2023 email explicitly stated, “Here is our Notice to Take Deposition of Mrs. Nail on July 12, 2023 starting at 2:00 p in your office as agreed.” Her signature again listed her Whaley Law Firm contact details and reminded recipients of the new email address.

On June 6, 2023, Beth Alexander replied, “Great….thanks,” in response to the scheduling of the deposition. The thread reiterates the exchange regarding deposition location, with Beth asking whether the deposition would be at the plaintiff’s office or the defense office, and Sarena indicating a preference for Zoom but confirming the office option.

On July 11, 2023, Beth Alexander sent another update, stating that they had been unable to reach Ms. Nail to confirm the deposition for tomorrow and that Brian believed she would not show. She noted they had not been able to locate Ms. Nail since their initial conversation and that, if her status changed, she would let Sarena know.

In response to Beth’s July 11 message, Sarena Tuttle replied on July 11, 2023 at 12:05 p.m., writing, “Ok, thanks for the update. I will let Aaron & Bryce know as well.” This reply was sent from Sarena’s Whaley Law Firm inbox, with the message including her standard contact information and the reminder to use the new email address.

These communications also reflect the broader case context: Adkins & Downs v Stephanie Nail & Allstate, involving the client Juanita Nicole Downs, with the underlying matter related to a motor vehicle accident dated April 16, 2021. The deposition in question concerns the deposition of Mrs. Nail and was scheduled for July 12, 2023 at 2:00 p.m. in the agreed-upon location, with ongoing notes about whether the deposition would proceed given Nail’s availability.

The deposition was to be conducted for the case number 84274, with Aaron Whaley, Esquire of The Whaley Law Firm listed as the client on the scheduling notice. The case style identifies Stephanie Nail as the judge/witness, and the deposition location was to be at Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, Kentucky, phone 502-245-7474. The record also lists Destiny Adkins alongside Juanita Downs as the plaintiffs.

On July 11, 2023 at 4:10:29 PM UTC, Kristina Wenninger, Scheduling Manager at Kentuckiana Court Reporters, wrote to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm (cc’d Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley) stating that there was no problem with the deposition and that she would remove it from their calendar and later send cancellation confirmation. Earlier that same day, on July 11, 2023, at 11:34 AM, Kristina Wenninger sent an email attaching the confirmation for the proceeding scheduled for tomorrow and asked to review and confirm whether it should proceed as scheduled or if revisions were needed. The draft confirmation included checkboxes, with [X] Court Reporter selected and the other options—Videographer, Interpreter, Conference Room, ZOOM Connection, and Telephone Conference—left unchecked.

At 11:41 AM, July 11, 2023, Sarena Tuttle replied: “Good afternoon, We are still on for tomorrow. As far as I’m aware there have not been any cancellations.” Her signature identifies her as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with office address 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Moments after that, at 12:09 PM, July 11, 2023, Sarena Tuttle sent another message: “Unfortunately, just moments after responding the Defense did in fact cancel the deposition. My apologies.” The message included her updated contact details (again noting the new email address).

In the thread, there are additional confirmations from Kristina Wenninger dated July 11, 2023, including a reply of “Thank you!” with a small image attachment, followed by the standard Kentuckiana Court Reporters signature block listing their office address, phone, fax, and email.

Stephanie Nail, et al. The listed location remained Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Louisville, Kentucky, with the contact number 502-245-7474.

The email chain concludes with the standard confidentiality notice that accompanies these scheduling communications, noting that the information is intended for the addressee and may be privileged or confidential, and advising against filing copies publicly. The defense canceled the deposition just after the confirmation discussions occurred on July 11, 2023, leading to cancellation of the proceeding. This is a narrative update for the case of Juanita Nicole Downs, a motor vehicle accident (MVA) case dated April 16, 2021. The client is Juanita Nicole Downs. On Monday, July 24, 2023, at about 6:40 AM, Juanita Downs wrote from her iPhone: “Good morning was just reaching out for an update on our case.”

The following day, Tuesday, July 25, 2023, at 10:33:14 AM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an update to Juanita Downs with copies to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. The email’s subject was “Re: Update.” In the body, she wrote: Good morning Juanita, At this time, the Defendant Owner of the vehicle did not appear for her deposition. We are attempting to reschedule her deposition, unfortunately she has not been in touch with her counsel in some time. We will continue to attempt scheduling for due diligence. If we are unable to reschedule the deposition within a reasonable time frame, I will reach out to Aaron & Bryce for additional information as to how we will proceed.

The note includes the sender’s signature block: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Direct line: 502-357-9971; Office: 502-583-4022 ext 104; Email: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the parenthetical note “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Good morning Brian, 

I have not heard back from you in response to our letter dated 07/27/2023. We are still attempting to obtain the deposition of your client following the previous cancellation. 

 I understand that you may be having some difficulty reaching your client and can certainly sympathize with your situation. Unfortunately, if we cannot get some dates by Wednesday of next week, I will have to file the attached Motion to Compel. Hopefully we can get something scheduled and avoid any extraneous litigation.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This matter concerns Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. in Jefferson Circuit Court, docket number 22-CI-002878.

In the correspondence related to Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Brian Stempien at That Attorneys on August 11, 2023 at 11:31:51 a.m. Eastern Time. The message began, “Good morning Brian, I have not heard back from you in response to our letter dated 07/27/2023. We are still attempting to obtain the deposition of your client following the previous cancellation.” He acknowledged that the recipient may be having difficulty reaching their client and expressed sympathy for that situation. He warned that if dates could not be provided by Wednesday of the following week, he would have to file the attached Motion to Compel. He concluded by expressing hope that a schedule could be arranged to avoid extraneous litigation and thanked the recipient for their consideration, hoping to hear back soon.

The email included the sender’s professional details: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. It also contained a standard confidentiality notice stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; if received in error, the recipient is instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm, with no waiver of privilege and that the information should not be used or forwarded to anyone not intended to receive it.

Earlier, on Thursday, July 27, 2023 at 3:11 p.m., Bryce Koon sent another message to bstempien@thattorneys.com with the subject line “Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878).” The body simply stated, “Good afternoon, Please see the attached correspondence.” This message also carried the same confidentiality notice as described above and was signed with the same contact details for The Whaley Law Firm.

Both emails preserve the ongoing issue in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter: the attempt to obtain a deposition of the opposing party following a prior cancellation, and the potential filing of a Motion to Compel if scheduling is not achieved by the stated deadline.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd call from Client - Companion Recvd No Contact Ltr (???) - Do not see where a NCL was sent - Advised Client that Motion to Compel was filed & Granted - Awaiting DC to produce Def Nail - If Def Nail is not produced - AW or BK will reach out to both her & companion to discuss how that effects things moving forward - Client expressed understanding and will relay to Companion 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: August 24 2023
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on August 24, 2023 with Sarena regarding the motor vehicle accident case of Juanita Nicole Downs (Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021). The client, Juanita Nicole Downs, stated that she received a call from her companion; the companion reportedly received a No Contact Letter (NCL), though no NCL appears to have been sent. The client was advised that a Motion to Compel had been filed and granted. We are awaiting DC to produce Def Nail. If Def Nail is not produced, AW or BK will reach out to both the client and the companion to discuss how that affects things moving forward. The client expressed understanding and will relay this to the companion.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative covers communications in the matter of Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit Court, 22-CI-002878), involving Juanita Nicole Downs, the client in a motor vehicle accident case dated April 16, 2021.

On September 11, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, emailed Mr. Stempien at That Attorneys (bstempien@thattorneys.com) regarding the deposition of the client in the above-referenced case. In the subject line he referenced Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). In the body of the message, he reminded that on August 21, 2023 the Court entered an Order requiring the client to present for a deposition within 30 days from entry. He noted that the deadline was fast approaching and that they had received no update to date. He requested confirmation of whether the client would be able to attend the deposition so a date could be scheduled in the coming weeks. The message closed with thanks and included Koon’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email also contained a standard disclaimer stating that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; if received in error, the recipient was instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm, that no waiver of privilege shall apply, and not to use or forward the information to anyone not intended to receive it.

A follow-up message from the same attorney was sent on September 26, 2023, at 3:09 PM (Eastern Time). In this email, Koon again addressed counsel, stating, “Good afternoon counsel, I have still not heard anything back from you regarding your client’s deposition.” He referenced that “an Order was entered” and noted a garbled link, thttp://schemas.microsoft.com/office/2004/12/ommled, as part of that reference. He acknowledged that the opposing side might have had trouble contacting their client and asked for confirmation of whether they had been able to do so and whether any dates were available. He warned that if no deposition date was set in the coming days, he would be forced to file a motion for sanctions in this regard. The message was signed again with The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and included the standard confidentiality and privilege disclaimer identical to the prior email.

Both emails include The Whaley Law Firm’s address—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222—and its phone and fax numbers, and both contain the standard electronic-communications disclaimer indicating privileged information and directing error recipients to contact the firm and to refrain from sharing the content.
episodes.author: Bryce Koon

episodes.natural_language:
The case is Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021, involving client Juanita Nicole Downs.

On September 29, 2023, at 9:47:48 a.m. Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Juanita Downs regarding the process of settlement. The subject was Re: Process of settlement. In the message, Sarena explained that she was a bit confused about who had told Juanita the case was settled. She reminded Juanita that, during a conversation on August 24, 2023, she advised that the team was still attempting to take the deposition of the owner of the vehicle. At that time, a Motion to Compel the Deposition had been filed and the Defendant had been ordered to appear for a deposition within 30 days. As of that date, the Defendant had not appeared or been produced for the deposition. Bryce, an attorney with The Whaley Law Firm, had followed up on the order and had filed a Motion for Sanctions and a Default Judgment earlier in the week. Sarena explained that sanctions are penalties for not following a court order and that a Default Judgment is an order ruling in Juanita’s favor. The team was awaiting the Judge’s approval or objection to those motions. She closed by inviting Juanita to contact the firm directly if she had any further questions to discuss the matter in more detail. The email signature identified Sarena as a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address listed as 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. It provided direct and office phone numbers (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104) and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the note “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

Earlier, on September 28, 2023, at around 6:49 p.m., Juanita Downs wrote to the firm (from her iPhone) regarding her settlement. She stated that it had been over 30 days—the period she had been told they needed to settle—and that she had not heard anything from anyone and would like an update.

In summary, the client has been kept informed that the deposition of the vehicle owner was pursued via a Motion to Compel, with a court-ordered appearance within 30 days that had not yet occurred, and that sanctions and a possible Default Judgment were being sought, with the matter awaiting the Judge’s decision. Concurrently, Juanita requested an update on the settlement timeline, noting the 30-day expectation had passed.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

Process of settlement.

The file indicates that on September 28, 2023, Juanita Downs emailed The Whaley Law Firm from her iPhone to express concern about her settlement in the motor vehicle accident matter and to request an update. She stated that it had been over 30 days since she had been told a decision would be reached and that she had not heard from anyone, asking for an update.

The following day, September 29, 2023, at approximately 12:10 PM (the note shows 12:10?PM), Juanita wrote again requesting that Aaron or Bryce call her, noting that she had called a month earlier and had been told there had been no effort to contact her or her attorney and that the firm was pursuing a settlement.

Earlier that same day, at 9:47 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Juanita. She expressed that she was a bit confused about who had told Juanita that her case was settled. Sarena then recapped the status discussed during their August 24, 2023 conversation, explaining that they were still attempting to obtain the deposition of the owner of the vehicle. At that time, they had filed a Motion to Compel the deposition, and the defendant had been ordered to appear for a deposition within 30 days. The defendant had not appeared or been produced to date. She also noted that Bryce, an attorney with their office, had followed up on the order and had filed a Motion for Sanctions and a Default Judgment earlier in the week. Sarena clarified that sanctions are penalties for not following a court order and that a Default Judgment is an order ruling in Juanita’s favor. She added that they were awaiting the judge’s approval or objection to those motions and invited Juanita to contact them directly to discuss the matter in more detail. The communication included Sarena’s contact information and her role, along with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and the direct lines: D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the note to please use the new email address.

Later on September 29, 2023 at 12:12:29 PM, Sarena again sent a note stating, “I will forward your request to Aaron & Bryce,” reaffirming the plan to route Juanita’s request to the appropriate attorneys. The note also included Sarena’s professional signature with the same contact information and updated email address.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This matter concerns the settlement process for Ms. Downs in a motor vehicle accident case initiated on 4-16-2021.

On the evening of September 28, 2023, Ms. Downs emailed Sarena Tuttle at The Whaley Law Firm (sent from Ms. Downs’s iPhone) requesting a settlement update. She stated that she had been told last month that there were 30 days to make a decision and asked that Aaron or Bryce call her. She noted that she had called a month earlier and was told that there had been no contact from the opposing party or her attorney and that the firm was proceeding to settle.

On September 29, 2023, at 9:47 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied. She expressed confusion about who told Ms. Downs that the case was settled. Tuttle recalled that, in their August 24, 2023 conversation, she advised that they were still attempting to take the deposition of the owner of the vehicle. At that time, a Motion to Compel the Deposition had been filed, and the Defendant was ordered to appear for a deposition within 30 days. The Defendant has not appeared or been produced to date. Bryce, an attorney with The Whaley Law Firm, had followed up on the order and filed a Motion for Sanctions and Default Judgement earlier that week. Tuttle explained that sanctions are penalties for not following a court order and that a Default Judgement is an order ruling in the client’s favor. The firm was awaiting the Judge’s approval or objection to those motions and invited Ms. Downs to contact them with any further questions. Her contact details appeared in the signature block of the email, which listed The Whaley Law Firm’s address and contact numbers, and noted a new email address for Sarena M. Tuttle.

Earlier the same day, September 29, 2023, at approximately 12:10 PM, Ms. Downs sent another message reiterating that it had been over 30 days since she was told a settlement would be required, and requesting that Aaron or Bryce call. She again stated that she had called a month prior and was told that there was no effort by the opposing party to contact the firm or her attorney and that the firm was pursuing a settlement.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This concerns the Jefferson Circuit Court case Adkins and Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jeff. Cir. 22-CI-002878).

In late September 2023, communications began regarding the Adkins and Downs matter. On September 28, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an electronic message to counsel in the Jefferson Circuit Court matter, with the subject line Re: Adkins and Downs v. Nail, et al. (Jeff. Cir. 22-CI-002878). In that message, he wrote, “Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” The message included the usual attorney-client privilege disclaimer, stating that the electronic transmission is intended only for the named recipient and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, no privilege waivers apply, and the information should not be used or forwarded to third parties not intended to receive it. The Whaley Law Firm contact details appeared in the signature block.

On October 7, 2023, at 7:05 PM, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC replied to Bryce Koon, with copies to acewen@ewenandkinney.com, Sarena Tuttle, and Beth Alexander. In that message, Stempien stated that they had actually located Ms. Nail and asked how Wednesday, October 18, at 2:00 o’clock in their office would work for a meeting. The email was sent from Stempien’s iPhone and carried the same standard confidentiality disclaimer as the prior message.

Three days later, on October 9, 2023, at 11:16:15 AM (Eastern Time), Bryce Koon responded with, “Counsel, This will work for us.” He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with his Louisville, Kentucky office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and contact numbers Phone: (502) 365-5043 and Fax: (502) 237-3207. The reply, like the others, included the attorney-client privilege disclaimer indicating that the message is intended only for the named recipient, and providing instructions if received in error, including advising to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not to use or forward the information. The email was sent to Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley, with copies to acewen@ewenandkinney.com, Sarena Tuttle, and Beth Alexander, maintaining the same cautionary privacy language found in prior messages.
