episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This note captures an email exchange among counsel regarding the matter Adkins and Downs v. Nail, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court docket number 22-CI-002878, in connection with the Juanita Downs motor vehicle accident case.

The earliest item in the thread, dated September 28, 2023, comes from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm. In that message to opposing counsel, he requested that they review the attached filing that had been filed that day in Jefferson Circuit Court. His signature block lists The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information, followed by the standard confidential and privilege notices typical of attorney communications, including warnings about attorney-client privilege, the prohibition on dispersion if received in error, and instructions to contact the sender and delete the message if it was sent to the wrong recipient. The email also includes a standard disclaimer about not creating an attorney-client relationship by email, and a Circular 230 tax disclosure stating that the document may not contain complete tax disclosures and that tax advice should not be relied upon for penalties or used in marketing materials.

On October 7, 2023, Brian D. Stempien, of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, replied to Bryce Koon, indicating that they had located Ms. Nail and asking whether Wednesday, October 18 at 2:00 p.m. in their office would work for him. Stempien closed with his firm’s contact details, and the message was marked as sent from an iPhone. The message body did not include new attachments but set the schedule inquiry for a meeting.

On October 9, 2023, at 11:16 a.m., Bryce Koon responded to both Brian Stempien and Aaron Whaley with the simple confirmation: “Counsel, This will work for us.” His message again included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and the standard confidentiality disclaimer indicating the message’s privileged status and that it is intended only for the named recipient, with instructions to contact the firm if received in error and not to disclose or use the information.

Later on October 9, 2023, at 3:26 p.m. (15:26:31 +0000), Brian Stempien sent another reply to Bryce Koon (and to Aaron Whaley) stating: “Assuming this works for Campbell, we will get this set up. Let me know if you are not alright with doing this here. I would like to minimize the logistical challenges for obvious reasons.” Stempien again provided his firm’s contact information and included the customary Privileged and Confidential notice, along with the IRS Circular 230 tax disclosure language applicable to tax communications, and the standard warnings that the information is attorney-privileged and confidential, that no attorney-client relationship is created by emailing, and that if the message is received in error, the recipient should notify the sender and delete it.

The thread also makes clear multiple standard email disclosures. Each message contains a confidentiality notice asserting attorney privilege, a warning that dissemination or copying is prohibited if the reader is not the intended recipient, and instructions to contact the sender and delete the message if received in error. The notices also reiterate that sending or receipt of the email does not establish an attorney-client relationship, and one message references the caveats required by Circular 230 regarding tax communications.

In addition to the substantive content, the messages include the participants’ contact details. Brian D. Stempien’s signature lists Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, located in the Jefferson Marders Building at 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, with office phone (502) 245-7474, fax (502) 245-7025, toll-free (866) 431-3599, email bstempien@thattorneys.com, and website http://www.thslaw.co. Bryce Koon’s signature lists The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone (502) 365-5043 and fax (502) 237-3207.

In sum, the email chain documents the coordination of counsel regarding the Adkins and Downs v. Nail matter: (1) an attachment of a filed filing in Jefferson Circuit Court on September 28, 2023; (2) confirmation that Ms. Nail had been located and a proposed in-office meeting set for Wednesday, October 18 at 2:00 p.m.; (3) a confirmatory response that the suggested timing works for the other side; and (4) a final communication expressing willingness to proceed with the scheduling as proposed, with all messages accompanied by their customary confidentiality, privilege, and tax-disclosure notices.

From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Brian Stempien [BStempien@thattorneys.com](mailto:BStempien@thattorneys.com), "A. Campbell Ewen" [ACEwen@ewenandkinney.com](mailto:ACEwen@ewenandkinney.com)
CC: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com), Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
Date: Fri, 10 Nov 2023 12:06:25 -0500

Good afternoon Counselors,
 It appears we are ready to discuss mediation of this claim, if all
parties agree, please provide dates that you & your clients are available
for mediation via Zoom with Hon. Thomas Knopf.
 Per Judge Knopf's calendar, he is open several days in December and
is open most of January. December 7, 8, 11, 13, 15, 20, 21, 22 are all
available all day.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
On November 10, 2023, at 12:06:25 PM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email regarding mediation scheduling for the case Juanita Downs & Destiny Adkins v. Stephanie Nail et al. The email was addressed to counsel for the defendants, Brian Stempien of That Attorneys and A. Campbell Ewen of Ewen and Kinney, with copies to Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. The subject line read: “Juanita Downs & Destiny Adkins v Stephanie Nail et. al. - Mediation Scheduling.” In the body of the message, Sarena stated that it appears the parties are ready to discuss mediation of the claim, and asked that, if all parties agreed, they provide dates on which they and their clients would be available for mediation via Zoom with Hon. Thomas Knopf. She noted that, per Judge Knopf’s calendar, he is open on several days in December and most of January, specifically that December 7, 8, 11, 13, 15, 20, 21, and 22 are all-day availabilities.

The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, including her role as Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, along with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her contact numbers were listed as D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email was given as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating it is the new email address.

Case: Juanita Nicole Downs – MVA matter dated 4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This note concerns the matter Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit Court, 22-CI-002878).

On January 16, 2024, in the Destiny Adkins case, a correspondence thread between counsel was exchanged regarding filings and a scheduling matter. Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager with The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, along with a copy to Bryce Koon and kpkinney, and Beth Alexander. In her message she stated that there should be three attachments and that she had reattached them. She asked to be informed if the Notice – Motion is still not visible and noted that the Motion Hour is set for January 22, 2024, at 8:25 a.m. She concluded by inviting any questions and providing her contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Direct line (502) 357-9971; Office (502) 583-4022 ext. 104; Email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note that this is a NEW email address.

Earlier that same day, Bryce Koon, also with The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Brian Stempien and kpkinney (cc’d to Sarena Tuttle) with the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). Bryce wrote, “Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” He signed with his name and title, providing his firm’s contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone (502) 365-5043; Fax (502) 364-9363. His signature block also included standard attorney disclaimers asserting the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged or protected information, with instructions to contact The Whaley Law Firm if received in error, and a note that no waiver of privilege has occurred. He also included that recipients should not use the information or forward it to third parties not intended to receive it. The signature contained a further notice that no attorney‑client relationship is created by sending or receiving the email, and referenced the firm’s disclaimer at www.thslaw.co. Additionally, there was an IRS Circular 230 disclaimer stating that if the document does not contain all required tax disclosures, one may not rely on any tax advice contained in the document to avoid penalties, and that no portion of the document may be used in marketing or promotional materials.

Later on January 16, 2024, at approximately 5:07 p.m. (the message shows “5:07?PM”), Brian D. Stempien replied to Bryce. He asked whether there was an intention to file a motion to amend the complaint, noting that what he could see was the amended complaint. His signature block identified him as Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with office address listed as the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243. His contact numbers included Office (502) 245-7474, Fax (502) 245-7025, Toll Free (866) 431-3599, and his email bstempien@thattorneys.com; his web address was http://www.thslaw.co. His email carried the same Privileged and Confidential notice found in the earlier messages, along with the standard disclaimer that no attorney‑client relationship is created by email and a reference to the firm’s disclosure under the same website. The IRS Circular 230 tax disclosure warning appeared as well.

Across these communications, the attachments referenced in the messages were indicated as three in total, with Bryce’s message noting the attachments were filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court, and Sarena’s subsequent note confirming the attachments had been reattached and inquiring about the visibility of the Notice – Motion. The thread includes the usual attorney‑client privilege and confidentiality disclaimers, a notice that no attorney‑client relationship is created by email, and the Circular 230 tax disclosures, all of which appear in the signatures of the correspondents.

From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: "A. Ewen" [ACEwen@ewenandkinney.com](mailto:ACEwen@ewenandkinney.com), Brian Stempien [BStempien@thattorneys.com](mailto:BStempien@thattorneys.com)

Date: Wed, 21 Feb 2024 15:04:45 -0500

Good afternoon Counselors,
 Please find attached the Motion for Special Bailiff filed moments ago
via CourtNet Envelope 7387377. It appears Defendant Demetrius Turner
received notice from the Sheriff and set up an appointment to be served,
however, per the Sheriff Mr. Turner did not show for this appointment and
has stopped responding to the Sheriff's attempts to contact/serve him. At
this time, we are requesting a Special Bailiff be appointed to perfect
service. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us
directly to discuss them in further detail.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

On February 21, 2024, at 3:04:45 PM Eastern, Sarena M. Tuttle, the Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to counsel A. Ewen and Brian Stempien, with Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon CC’ed. The message states that the Motion for Special Bailiff was attached and filed moments earlier via CourtNet Envelope 7387377. episodes.original_body:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Message from FG - Client call for update - States she left a prior message but had not received a call back - Called Client - Advised Special Bailiff Approved & Executed Service - We do have to wait 20-30 days to see if he responds - Advised if we have not received a response BK (or I) will follow with BI Insurance to see if they are going to provide him Counsel - If not, then BK will consider Default Judgement - Advised Client to give us a call around 07.15 if she has not heard back from us - Client expressed understanding and appreciated the update 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: June 27 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on June 27, 2024, with Sarena regarding the case of Juanita Nicole Downs (Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021). We received a message from FG; the client called for an update and stated that she had left a prior message but had not received a callback.

We spoke with the client and advised that Special Bailiff Approved & Executed Service had been completed. We explained that we must wait 20–30 days to see if the recipient responds. If we have not received a response, BK (or I) will follow with BI Insurance to see whether they will provide him counsel. If not, BK will consider Default Judgement. We advised the client to call around July 15 if she has not heard back from us. The client expressed understanding and appreciated the update.

Initial client contact on July 15, 2024, with Juanita Nicole Downs regarding the motor vehicle accident case Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. The client was calling to check for an update. episodes.natural_language:
This case note is for the file labeled Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021, reflecting client Juanita Nicole Downs. The note also references ongoing matter Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case number 22-CI-002878. The message header shows the communication originated from Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm and was sent to Brian Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with a broad distribution that included Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle of Whaley, as well as two Filevine project email addresses: Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021.

In a message related to Destiny Adkins v. Nail, Bryce Koon wrote to Brian Stempien with a conditional proposal. He stated that The Whaley Law Firm would agree to dismiss Brian’s client from the case if she amended her Answer and/or discovery responses to state that Defendant Turner was operating her vehicle with permission. He added that, apart from that amendment, he did not believe a voluntary dismissal of Brian’s client could be achieved. He concluded by inviting questions and providing his contact details: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The body and signature blocks include the standard attorney-client privilege and confidentiality disclaimers typical of firm email communications, as well as a tax-related notice required by Circular 230.

The chain of communications in this matter also includes several prior and related exchanges. On January 16, 2024, Bryce Koon wrote to counsel (and included others in the cc line), with the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). The message stated: “Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” The message was from Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm, and it indicated that a filing had been made in Jefferson Circuit Court; the signature block provided the firm’s contact information and reiterated standard privileged/confidentiality language.

Later in the year, on July 22, 2024 at 5:13 PM, Brian Stempien sent a message to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley (with Sarena Tuttle CC’d) asking, “Aaron and Bryce: Are you guys going to let Ms. Nail out of this case? Give me a call if you would like to discuss.” This message carried the same general privilege and confidentiality disclaimers that appear in the chain, along with the standard firm signatures and contact details.

Again on September 3, 2024, Brian Stempien sent a succinct inquiry asking, “Guys: Are you going to let my lady out of this case?” with a closing that included his full name, firm, address (Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243), contact numbers, and a standard attorney-client disclaimer. The chain also includes the corresponding email from Bryce Koon in the same thread, reiterating the ongoing discussion about potential dismissal and the conditions under which any dismissal might be considered, as well as the familiar disclaimers and the IRS Circular 230 tax disclaimer that accompanies tax-related communications.

In summary, the file shows a sequence of communications among counsel about the Destiny Adkins v. Nail case, including a January 2024 filing notice, a July 2024 inquiry about whether Ms. Nail would be released from the case, a September 2024 follow-up question about the same issue, and a key conditional offer from Bryce Koon in a later email stating that a dismissal of a client could be achieved if an amendment to a pleading would indicate that Defendant Turner operated the vehicle with permission. The note also documents ongoing involvement related to the Downs MVA file, with Filevine project email addresses associated to Destiny Adkins MVA and Juanita Downs MVA.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). The note identifies Juanita Nicole Downs as the client, tied to a motor vehicle accident dated 4/16/2021 (MVA). The file tracking and communications relate to the Destiny Adkins matter, with Filevine project emails included for both Destiny Adkins MVA (04/16/2021) and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA (4/16/2021).

On September 3, 2024, at 12:19:10 PM Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, KY, sent an email to Brian D. Stempien, Esq., of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, also in Louisville. The message was copied to Aaron Whaley, Esq.; Sarena Tuttle; and to Filevine project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA. The subject of the email mirrored the Destiny Adkins case. In the body, Koon stated that “we will agree to dismiss your client from the case if she amends her Answer and/or discovery responses to state that Defendant Turner was operating her vehicle with permission.” He added that, apart from this conditional dismissal, he did not believe a voluntary dismissal of the client could be agreed to. He invited any questions and provided his direct contact information, including his phone number (502) 365-5043 and fax (502) 237-3207, and identified The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. The email included standard attorney‑client privilege language, noting that the message was intended only for the named recipient and that receipt in error should be reported to the firm, with no waiver of privilege and no attorney‑client relationship presumed. It also contained a Circular 230 tax‑related disclaimer.

Earlier that same day, at approximately 12:10 PM, Brian D. Stempien responded with a brief, pointed inquiry: “Guys: Are you going to let my lady out of this case?” He signed with his full firm information, including his office address at the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, along with office phone (502) 245-7474, fax (502) 245-7025, toll‑free line (866) 431‑3599, and email bstempien@thattorneys.com. His message also carried the same blanket attorney‑client and IRS disclosures customary to the firm, indicating that sending or receiving emails does not establish an attorney‑client relationship and reiterating the general confidentiality and privilege notices.

The email thread includes a prior exchange dating back to July 22, 2024. In that earlier message, Brian Stempien sent a reply to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley at 5:13 PM, asking, “Are you guys going to let Ms. Nail out of this case? Give me a call if you would like to discuss.” Stempien’s signature block followed, containing the same practice address in Louisville and the same contact numbers, along with the customary privilege and confidentiality disclaimers.

Even earlier, on July 22, 2024, Bryce Koon had sent a message to Brian Stempien and kpkinney@ewenandkinney.com (at 1:10 PM) with the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). Koon thanked counsel and stated, “Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville address and phone/fax numbers, followed by the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

The chain also shows the January 16, 2024 exchange. In that message, Bryce Koon wrote at 1:10 PM to Brian Stempien and kpkinney@ewenandkinney.com, CC’ing Sarena Tuttle, with the subject Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). He began, “Good afternoon counsel,” and concluded, “Please see attached filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court.” Once again, the signature identified W. Bryce Koon, The Whaley Law Firm, and included the same address and contact details, along with the standard attorney‑client privilege language.

In sum, the documented communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC concern the Destiny Adkins v. Nail matter in Jefferson Circuit Court (22-CI-002878) and the related participation of Juanita Nicole Downs in the MVA matters dated 4/16/2021. The central substantive proposal across the latest exchange is that Downs could be dismissed from the case if she amend her Answer and/or discovery responses to assert that Defendant Turner operated the vehicle with permission. The communications include multiple standard confidentiality and privilege disclosures, and the emails reference filevine project accounts for the Destiny Adkins and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA matters.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. Re: Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). From Brian Stempien [BStempien@thattorneys.com] to Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com], CC: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com], Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com], "Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address" [DestinyAdkinsMVAZ1161425@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com], and "Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address" [JuanitaNicoleDownsMVAZ954678@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com]. Date: Tue, 3 Sep 2024 16:33:53 +0000.

In the message, Brian D. Stempien, of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, writing from the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243, told Bryce Koon that “Yeh.. not going to happen. I guess we will have to file something.” He provided the firm’s contact details: Office (502) 245-7474; Fax (502) 245-7025; Toll Free 1 (866) 431-3599; bstempien@thattorneys.com; and the firm website www.thslaw.co. He included a standard attorney-privilege disclaimer and confidentiality notice declaring that the email, its attachments, and the information within are privileged and confidential and intended for the named recipient, that no attorney-client relationship is created by sending or receiving the email, and that if the reader is not the intended recipient the information should not be disseminated or used; recipients are instructed to notify the sender and delete the message. The disclaimer also cites an IRS Circular 230 warning about tax advice, noting that the document may not contain all required disclosures and that nothing in the email should be used to avoid tax penalties or in marketing materials.

The September 3, 2024 communication from Brian included the following: “Yeh.. not going to happen. I guess we will have to file something.” The email was sent to Bryce Koon and CC’d Aaron Whaley, Sarena Tuttle, Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address. The email carried the same Privileged and Confidential notice as in the prior correspondence, reiterating that there is no attorney-client relationship by virtue of email and reiterating the IRS Circular 230 warning.

Earlier in the same thread, Bryce Koon replied on September 3, 2024 at 12:19 PM, addressed to Brian Stempien and copied to Aaron Whaley, Sarena Tuttle, Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address. Bryce stated that the parties would agree to dismiss Brian’s client from the case if she amended her Answer and/or discovery responses to state that Defendant Turner was operating her vehicle with permission. Bryce added that, outside of that amendment, he did not believe a voluntary dismissal of Brian’s client could be agreed to. Bryce closed by inviting Brian to contact him with any questions. Bryce’s signature block identified The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone (502) 365-5043 and fax (502) 237-3207, and included the same standard electronic-disclaimer language about privilege, confidentiality, and the lack of an attorney-client relationship, along with the IRS Circular 230 warning.

Also on September 3, 2024, at approximately 12:10 PM, Brian Stempien sent a follow-up message with the subject line “Re: Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878).” He wrote, “Guys: Are you going to let my lady out of this case?” This message was sent from Brian Stempien at Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, using the same contact information and incorporating the same Privileged and Confidential notice and disclaimers about attorney-client privilege and tax disclosures.

Earlier in the thread, on Monday, July 22, 2024 at 5:13 PM, Brian Stempien had written to Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley (with Sarena Tuttle cc’d) regarding Destiny Adkins, et al. v. Stephanie Nail, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878). In that message, Brian asked, “Are you guys going to let Ms. Nail out of this case? Give me a call if you would like to discuss.” The email again carried the same firm signature block with the firm’s address in Louisville, phone and toll-free numbers, email address, and website, and it included the same Privileged and Confidential Notice and No Attorney-Client Relationship disclaimer, along with the Circular 230 tax-disclosure language.

In all, the record reflects a sequence of communications among counsel regarding the Destiny Adkins v. Nail case, with July 22, 2024 and September 3, 2024 having multiple messages between Brian Stempien and Bryce Koon (and to or from Aaron Whaley and Sarena Tuttle) about the possibility of dismissing a client and specifically about whether an amendment to pleadings would permit a voluntary dismissal. The communications also show that the emails contained standard confidentiality and privilege notices, that no attorney-client relationship is created by email, and that tax-related disclosures under Circular 230 are included where applicable. The note header ties this thread to the unrelated case of Juanita Nicole Downs, the MVA case dated 4-16-2021, and the Filevine project addresses for Destiny Adkins and Juanita Downs.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Call from Client - Checking Status

Advised DC Nail is trying to get his client out of the case - advised BK is not letting her out unless she admits she lied & let Def Turner drive the vehicle but DC is not going to let that happen - Client is happy to hear we are not letting Def Nail out so easily - Advised her we will update her as soon as we know more 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: September 04 2024
episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on September 4, 2024, with Juanita Nicole Downs regarding the motor vehicle accident case (Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021). Sarena received a call from the client to check the status. Sarena advised that DC Nail is trying to get his client out of the case; BK is not letting her out unless she admits she lied and let Def Turner drive the vehicle, but DC is not going to let that happen. The client was happy to hear we are not letting Def Nail out so easily. Sarena advised her that we would update her as soon as we know more.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

In the matter of Adkins & Downs v. Turner, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878), correspondence began with a message from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent on November 12, 2024. The email was addressed to Eric S. Rice, Esq., of Rice Gumm, PLLC, with Daniel Gumm cc’d, and it also included cc’s to Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 via Filevine, Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 via Filevine, and Brian Stempien. The subject line read “Adkins & Downs v. Turner, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 22-CI-002878).” Bryce stated that attached was the motion filed that day and that the motion was set for Monday, November 25, 2024. He explained that if they received the client’s responses prior to that date, he would remand the motion, and he invited any questions. The message concluded with Bryce’s signature, listing The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone number 502-365-5043, and fax 502-237-3207, followed by a standard attorney-client confidentiality disclaimer.

Subsequently, on November 21, 2024, at approximately 10:22 AM, Eric Rice replied. He reported that he had spoken with Demetrius that morning and that he would be leaving tomorrow to go home for Thanksgiving, not returning until December 2. He stated he could not meet with Demetrius until December 4 in order to obtain discovery responses for Bryce. He then asked Bryce if he could remand his MTC. Eric Rice’s signature block followed, including his title as Partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC, with contact details: 502-290-1075, eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243, and the firm website www.ricegummlaw.com, along with a confidentiality notice clarifying that the email and attachments may contain privileged information and should only be viewed by the intended recipient.

Earlier, Bryce had sent another message on November 12, 2024, at 12:10 PM, to Eric Rice and Daniel Gumm, with Destiny Adkins MVA and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA Filevine email addresses cc’d, and Brian Stempien cc’d. The subject was the same case. Bryce advised counsel that the attached motion had been filed that day and that the motion was set for Monday, November 25, 2024. He reiterated that if they received the client’s responses prior to that date, he would remand the motion, and he invited any questions. This message also included Bryce’s standard contact information and a confidentiality disclaimer.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd FG Message Companion Called for Update - Sent Update via Text:

Good morning Juanita,
 Thank you for reaching out. Currently your claim is scheduled for Motion Hour on December 9, 2024 to compel Defendant Turner's Responses to the Discovery Requests sent to him. Unfortunately, there has been a significant delay due to Defendant Turner's criminal history and having been recently re-arrested. Once we receive his Discovery Responses, we will reach out to you & Destiny with a more detailed updated. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

__Details:__ Recvd Client Text:
Hey was wondering if there are any updates?

Replied to Client:
Good afternoon Juanita,
On December 17th, we received notice that the Defense Counsel for Mr. Turner Responded to the Discovery Requests previously discussed. Once Bryce has determined that the responses are sufficient, we will begin the scheduling of Depositions. Once the Depositions are scheduled, we will forward notice to you as well as Destiny, as to the date, time & location. We typically allow 30 days, post receipt of Discovery Responses for review, discussion, and decision making, however this is a loose time frame and the decision may be made sooner. We will definitely keep you posted as things progress. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me or Bryce directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

Reviewing activity in Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 between 12/25/2024 and 1/24/2025...

Good morning Juanita,
 Thank you for reaching out. Currently your claim is scheduled for Motion Hour on December 9, 2024 to compel Defendant Turner's Responses to the Discovery Requests sent to him. Once we receive his Discovery Responses, we will reach out to you & Destiny with a more detailed updated. If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at (502) 583-4022 Ext 104 or Bryce at Ext 114. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Text yesterday (Was reviewing cases w/BK) - Responded today:

Good morning Juanita,
I apologize for not responding yesterday. Currently, we are attempting to schedule the Deposition of Mr. Turner. The Defense has taken the position that we can not prove Mr. Turner was the driver of the vehicle and we feel that will be remedied with his testimony. Once the Deposition has formally been scheduled, we will update you on the date, though you will not need to be in attendance. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

__Date & Time__: January 29 2025

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

In the matter of Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., the file notes reflect a February 2025 set of communications concerning the scheduling of Mr. Turner’s deposition. The correspondence involves The Whaley Law Firm, represented by Sarena M. Tuttle, and Rice Gumm, PLLC, represented by Eric S. Rice, with multiple participants copied on the exchanges and attached Filevine project email addresses for related MVA clients Destiny Adkins (MVA 04/16/2021) and Juanita Nicole Downs (MVA 4/16/2021).

On January 21, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to counsel requesting assistance in scheduling Mr. Turner’s deposition and asked that they provide availability for the coming weeks. He asked for Mr. Turner’s availability and concluded by thanking counsel for their attention, signing as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and contact details, and including the standard attorney‑client privilege disclaimer in his signature. The recipients included Eric Rice and Daniel Gumm, with copies to Brian Stempien and to the Filevine Project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA (04/16/2021) and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA (4/16/2021), as well as Sarena Tuttle.

On January 28, 2025, Bryce Koon followed up, again requesting an update on the deposition scheduling. He asked counsel to provide any available information and closed with thanks, again listing his contact details and attaching the same party and Filevine project recipients as in the prior message, along with the standard disclaimer in his email signature.

On January 31, 2025, Eric S. Rice replied, stating that he had not yet been able to speak with his client about the deposition. His message identified himself as a partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC, and included his direct line and firm contact information, along with the Confidentiality Notice typical to his firm’s emails.

On February 4, 2025, Eric Rice responded with specific available times for Mr. Turner: he could be available at 3:30 p.m. on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20, 2025, if those dates worked for the other side. The message was sent from Eric S. Rice, with his signature block including his title, phone number, email, and firm address.

On February 5, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied that, among the proposed dates, the only one that works for their office is February 20. She noted that their office has several mediations and depositions already scheduled for the month. She asked whether Mr. Turner would still be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at the opposing counsel’s office. If the client remains incarcerated, she said they would need to check with the jail regarding the process and availability. She included her contact information and stated the note about a new email address, and also their standard confidentiality admonition in the email footer.

For reference, the email chain contains the following participants and details: Sarena Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note of a new email address), Eric S. Rice (Partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC; 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; 502-290-1075; eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com), W. Bryce Koon, Esq. (The Whaley Law Firm; same Louisville address and contact details as above), Daniel Gumm (Rice Gumm, PLLC), Brian Stempien (email listed), and Filevine project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA (DestinyAdkinsMVAZ1161425@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com) and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA (JuanitaNicoleDownsMVAZ954678@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com). The case caption remains Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., with the client listed as Juanita Nicole Downs in the underlying MVA matter dated 4/16/2021. Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This entry covers the deposition scheduling communications in the matter Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., with Ms. Downs identified as a client in a motor vehicle accident that occurred on 04/16/2021. The email thread includes counsel from Rice Gumm, PLLC and The Whaley Law Firm, and references Filevine project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021, as well as a contact for Sarena Tuttle. The chain also lists the following addresses and contact details for the sending firm: Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Suite 200, Louisville, KY 40243; phone 502-290-1075; website www.ricegummlaw.com. Each message contains the standard confidentiality notice.

The latest communication in the thread is an email from Eric S. Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC, sent February 4, 2025 at 19:06:01 +0000 to Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm and Daniel Gumm, with Brian Stempien, Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, and Sarena Tuttle copied. The subject line is RE: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. In this message, Rice informs Bryce that Mr. Turner can be available at 3:30 PM on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20, should any of those dates work for scheduling Mr. Turner’s deposition.

Earlier in the thread, Eric S. Rice had written on January 31, 2025 at 9:55 AM, addressed to Bryce Koon and Daniel Gumm with Brian Stempien, Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, and Sarena Tuttle copied. In that email, Rice apologized that he had not yet been able to speak with his client.

Prior to that, on January 28, 2025 at 3:28 PM, Bryce Koon, Esq., sent a message to Eric Rice and Daniel Gumm, with Brian Stempien, Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, and Sarena Tuttle copied. Bryce requested an update on the deposition scheduling and expressed appreciation for any information.

The earliest message in the chain is from Bryce Koon on January 21, 2025 at 12:42 PM (time shown as 12:42?PM in the record). In that note, Bryce asked counsel to assist with scheduling Mr. Turner’s deposition and requested availability for the coming weeks, asking for the other side’s help in providing Mr. Turner’s availability to facilitate setting the deposition.

For reference, the chain shows the following participants and recipients: Eric S. Rice, Partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC; Bryce Koon, Esq., and Daniel Gumm as recipients on various messages; CCs include Brian Stempien, Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 - Filevine Project Email Address, and Sarena Tuttle. The communications consistently include confidentiality notices and standard firm signatures with office address, phone number, and website.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. matter, regarding the MVA related to Juanita Nicole Downs on 4/16/2021, the Whaley Law Firm coordinated scheduling for a deposition of Mr. Turner. The exchange began with an email on January 21, 2025, from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, to Eric S. Rice, Esq., of Rice Gumm, PLLC, requesting Mr. Turner’s deposition availability for the coming weeks.

Bryce followed up on January 28, 2025, asking for any update. In a subsequent email dated January 31, 2025, Eric Rice replied that he had not yet been able to speak with his client. That message was sent to Bryce Koon and Daniel Gumm, with Brian Stempien and two Filevine project email addresses—Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021—cc’d, along with Sarena Tuttle.

On February 4, 2025, Eric Rice wrote again, stating that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 p.m. on February 12 or 14, and also on February 18, 19, or 20, if those dates worked.

Then, on February 5, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, responded that the only date that would work for their office was February 20. She noted that they already had several mediations and depositions scheduled for the month. She asked whether Mr. Turner would still be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at the opposing counsel’s office; if the client remained incarcerated, they would need to check with the jail about its process and availability.

For reference, Sarena Tuttle’s contact details are The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address). Eric S. Rice’s contact details are Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; office phone 502-290-1075; email eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com. The communications also included as cc the Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 Filevine project email address, Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 Filevine project email address, and Sarena Tuttle, with the matter titled “RE: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al.”

episodes.natural_language:
This note documents a chain of communications about scheduling the deposition of Mr. Turner in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. matter, with the case file referenced as Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021. The CC list includes Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 via Filevine project email addresses, as well as the Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm, PLLC contacts. The Filevine project email addresses shown are DestinyAdkinsMVAZ1161425@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com for Destiny Adkins and JuanitaNicoleDownsMVAZ954678@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com for Juanita Downs.

The participants in the email thread include Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct lines are D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email address is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address. The opposing counsel is Eric S. Rice, a partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC, whose office is at 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243. His contact details include a phone number of 502-290-1075 and email eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com, along with the firm’s website www.ricegummlaw.com and a confidentiality notice in his emails.

The thread begins with a series of scheduling inquiries from The Whaley Law Firm’s Bryce Koon regarding Mr. Turner’s deposition. On January 21, 2025 at 12:42 PM, Bryce emailed counsel requesting Mr. Turner’s deposition availability for the coming weeks. He followed up on January 28, 2025 at 3:28 PM, asking for any update. On January 31, 2025 at 9:55 AM, Eric Rice replied that he had not yet been able to speak with his client.

Eric Rice subsequently proposed potential deposition times on February 4, 2025 at 2:06 PM: Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 PM on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20 if those dates worked. On February 5, 2025 at 12:00 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied that the only date that works for The Whaley Law Firm’s office would be February 20, and she asked whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at Rice Gumm’s office; if the client were incarcerated, they would need to check with the Jail regarding process and availability. She signed as Sarena M. Tuttle, noting her title and the firm’s contact information, and reminding recipients of the new email address.

Later on February 5, 2025, at 1:50 PM, Eric Rice responded that Mr. Turner would be at his office. Then at 1:56 PM, Sarena Tuttle sent a follow-up message stating that February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm would be the date and time to confirm with Mr. Stempien.

Throughout the thread, the signatures for the participants include the standard confidentiality notices common to these communications, the Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm contact details, and the filevine project email addresses referenced above. The exchange confirms that February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm’s offices was the working date and time under consideration, with the understanding that if Mr. Turner were incarcerated, their process with the jail would need to be reviewed. The deposition location was proposed to be at Rice & Gumm’s office, pending Mr. Turner’s status, and the parties remained responsive to confirm the final arrangements.

Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This note concerns the matter Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., with Destiny Adkins MVA on 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA on 04/16/2021. The record shows correspondence among the Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm, PLLC to coordinate a deposition or related proceeding involving Mr. Turner, with Filevine project email addresses listed for both Destiny Adkins and Juanita Nicole Downs.

In early February 2025, the scheduling discussion began with Eric S. Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC, who indicated that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 PM on certain dates: February 12/14, 18, 19, or 20, if those dates worked. He added that Mr. Turner would be at Rice & Gumm’s office for the deposition. Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied on February 5, 2025, stating that the only date that worked for their office among those proposed was February 20, 2025, and she noted that they had several mediations and depositions scheduled for the month. She asked whether Mr. Turner would still be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at Rice & Gumm’s office, adding that if his client were incarcerated they would need to check with the jail about processes and availability.

Earlier in the thread, Eric Rice had written on February 5, 2025 at 1:50 PM that Mr. Turner would be present at his office. This followed an earlier message from February 4, 2025, in which Eric Rice stated that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 PM on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20 if those dates worked.

The chain also shows prior communications: on January 31, 2025, Eric Rice advised that he had not yet been able to speak with his client. He suggested dates for availability and provided his contact information. On January 28, 2025, Bryce Koon had sent a message to Eric Rice and Daniel Gumm with others cc’d, though the contents of that particular email are not summarized in detail here.

When the February 5 exchange continued, Sarena Tuttle reiterated the question about whether February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm would work for Mr. Turner, while also confirming the involvement of Destiny Adkins and Juanita Downs as part of the Filevine Project email addresses for their respective MVA matters.

On February 6, 2025, Krista Rice responded from Rice Gumm, PLLC, noting a scheduling conflict with February 20 and asking whether any of February 24, 26, 27, or 28 would work, in addition to proposing those alternatives. Later that same day, Sarena Tuttle replied, explaining that February 24 is a Monday reserved for local motion hours and February 28 is a Friday reserved for Fayette motion hours. She indicated that the firm was available on February 26 or 27 but required an earlier start time of 1:00 PM.

The email chain is dated February 6, 2025, with the thread titled Re: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., and includes the standard confidentiality notices typical of the correspondence between law firms. The Whaley Law Firm contact information for Sarena M. Tuttle is listed as: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, D: (502) 357-9971, O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to please use the new email address.

In summary, the parties discussed scheduling a deposition related to Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., involving the MVA cases on April 16, 2021, for Destiny Adkins and Juanita Downs. The Whaley firm could accommodate February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm if Mr. Turner could attend there, but due to conflicts and Mr. Turner’s status, alternate dates were proposed. The Whaley firm suggested February 26 or 27, with a required start time of 1:00 PM, and warned against February 24 and February 28 due to existing commitments (local and Fayette motion hours, respectively). The parties also maintained the Filevine project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA and Juanita Downs MVA as part of the case records.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. The client is Juanita Nicole Downs, involved in a motor vehicle accident dated April 16, 2021. The note documents a series of email communications about scheduling a deposition in the matter Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al.

The exchanges began with The Whaley Law Firm on January 21, 2025, when Bryce Koon, an attorney with The Whaley Law Firm, asked for Mr. Turner’s deposition availability for the coming weeks. On January 28, 2025, Bryce followed up, requesting an update on availability. On January 31, 2025, Eric S. Rice, a partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC, replied that he had not yet been able to speak with his client.

On February 4, 2025, Eric Rice stated that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 p.m. on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20, if those dates would work. The next day, February 5, 2025, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied that the only date that works for their office would be February 20th, acknowledging that their calendar includes several mediations and depositions that month. She asked whether Mr. Turner would still be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at Rice Gumm, and if the client were incarcerated, they would need to coordinate with the jail regarding processes and availability. Later on February 5, Eric Rice responded, “He’ll be here at my office.”

That same day, February 5, 2025 at 12:00 p.m., Sarena Tuttle sent a follow-up noting that February 20 is the only date that works for their office and reiterating the consideration of the client’s incarceration status and whether the deposition would occur at the office or elsewhere, including the need to check with the jail if incarcerated. At approximately 1:50 p.m. on February 5, Eric Rice replied that Mr. Turner would be at Rice Gumm’s office for the deposition.

At 1:56 p.m. on February 5, Sarena Tuttle followed up with, “Thank you so much for the confirmation. Mr. Stempien, does February 20, 2025 at 3:30 p.m. at Rice & Gumm, work for you?” This indicates a tentative confirmation of the February 20, 2025, 3:30 p.m. time at Rice & Gumm, subject to Mr. Stempien’s availability.

On February 6, 2025, Krista Rice, the firm administrator at Rice Gumm, PLLC, sent a message noting a scheduling conflict for February 20 and asking for guidance on whether any of the alternative dates—February 24, February 26, February 27, or February 28—would work.

For reference, the parties involved include The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager; Bryce Koon, Esq.; Daniel Gumm), Rice Gumm, PLLC (Eric S. Rice, Partner; Krista Rice, Firm Administrator), and the clients listed in the Filevine project addresses: Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021. The Whaley Law Firm is located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and Rice Gumm, PLLC is located at 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243. The communications include standard confidentiality notices and indicate new email addresses for some recipients (e.g., Sarena Tuttle’s note to use a new email address).

In summary, the parties were attempting to schedule Mr. Turner’s deposition, with Feb. 20, 2025 at 3:30 p.m. at Rice & Gumm being proposed and then reevaluated due to a scheduling conflict, with alternative dates of Feb. 24, 26, 27, or 28, 2025 being suggested, all within a back-and-forth spanning January 21 to February 6, 2025.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs.

In the matter of Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., the following series of scheduling emails occurred in early February 2025 between Rice Gumm, PLLC and The Whaley Law Firm, with the involved participants and notices attached to the case of Juanita Nicole Downs (MVA 4/16/2021). The communications concern arranging a deposition for Mr. Turner, who appears to be incarcerated.

On January 31, 2025, Eric S. Rice, a partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC, wrote to Bryce Koon and Daniel Gumm, cc’ing Brian Stempien and the Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021 Filevine project addresses. In that message, he apologized for not having spoken with his client yet and stated that he had not been able to speak with his client as of that time.

Earlier, on January 28, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq. of The Whaley Law Firm replied to Eric Rice (and others cc’d) and asked for an update, indicating that he was following up on the previous request.

On February 4, 2025, Eric Rice replied to Bryce and Daniel, indicating that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 PM on February 12 or 14, and also on February 18, 19, or 20, if those dates worked. He concluded that message with his contact details and the Rice Gumm, PLLC information.

On February 5, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, responded to Krista Rice’s earlier message indicating that the only date among the options that would work for their office would be February 20, 2025. She noted that they have several mediations and depositions scheduled that month. She asked whether Mr. Turner would still be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at the defense office, and she added that if the client is incarcerated they would need to check with the jail regarding process and availability.

Later on February 5, 2025, at 1:50 PM, Eric Rice replied that Mr. Turner would be present at Rice Gumm’s office. He stated, “He’ll be here at my office.”

At 1:56 PM on February 5, 2025, Sarena Tuttle replied to Eric Rice, asking Mr. Stempien whether February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm would work for him.

The thread continued on February 6, 2025, with Sarena Tuttle noting that the 24th is a Monday and would be reserved for local motion hour, and the 28th is a Friday, which is Fayette motion hour. She stated that they were available on the 26th or 27th, but required an earlier start time of 1:00 PM.

In a follow-up message later on February 6, 2025, Krista Rice responded that Mr. Turner would not be available until 3:30 PM. She asked whether any of the following dates would work: March 6, March 12, March 13, March 19, or March 20.

For reference, the signatures and contact information embedded in these communications include: Krista Rice, Firm Administrator at Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; phone 502-290-1075; email admin@ricegummlaw.com; website www.ricegummlaw.com; with the confidentially notice typical to emails from Rice Gumm, PLLC. The Rice Gumm, PLLC firm’s office details appear in the messages as well as the “CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE” indicating privileged information.

The Whaley Law Firm’s representative details included Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new email address in the signature). The Whaley Law Firm was copied on the emails to incorporate their availability and scheduling constraints for Mr. Turner’s deposition in Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al.

Additional participants and project references included the Filevine project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021, which were included in the To/Cc lines across the thread.

In summary, the exchange established that Mr. Turner’s availability centered on 3:30 PM for potential deposition dates in mid-February (February 12/14, 18, 19, or 20) per Eric Rice, but The Whaley Law Firm indicated that February 20 was the only date workable for their office, contingent on Mr. Turner’s incarceration status and the logistics of where the deposition would occur. By February 6, 2025, there was ongoing discussion about alternate February dates (the 24th, 26th, 27th, and 28th) and an adjusted start time of 1:00 PM if those dates were pursued, with Mr. Turner’s availability being a critical factor, and eventual consideration of March dates (March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20) due to the 3:30 PM limitation.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. Re: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. The following is a record of email communications between the parties’ counsel and staff regarding scheduling a deposition for Mr. Turner in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter.

The correspondence began with Eric Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC, sending a message on February 4, 2025, to Bryce Koon and Daniel Gumm, noting that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 p.m. on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20 if those dates worked. Eric’s message is part of a thread that also includes Krista Rice, the firm administrator at Rice Gumm, as well as Sarena Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, and others such as Brian Stempien and Destiny Adkins and Juanita Downs via Filevine project addresses.

On February 5, 2025, at 12:00 p.m., Sarena Tuttle responded to Eric Rice. She stated that of the dates proposed by Eric, the only one that would work for The Whaley Law Firm’s office would be February 20. She noted that the firm already had several mediations and depositions scheduled for the month and asked whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated or if the deposition would be held at Rice Gumm’s office; if the client remained incarcerated, she said they would need to check with the jail regarding its process and availability. The message was copied to Krista Rice, with Eric Rice, Bryce Koon, Daniel Gumm, Brian Stempien, and others also on the CC line, including Filevine project addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA.

Later on February 5, 2025, at 1:56 p.m., Sarena reiterated essentially the same point in a follow-up message: the February 20 date remains the only date that works for The Whaley Law Firm, given their existing schedule of mediations and depositions. She again asked whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated or if the deposition would take place at Rice Gumm’s office, noting that if the client was incarcerated they would need to coordinate with the jail for its process and availability.

Earlier that day, at 1:50 p.m., Eric Rice replied with a simple acknowledgment: “He’ll be here at my office.” Eric signed as a Partner at Rice Gumm, PLLC, with contact information listed as 502-290-1075 and eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com, and the firm’s Louisville address at 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243, along with the firm’s website.

On February 5, 2025, at 12:00 p.m. again, Sarena had previously reminded that the only date workable for their office was February 20 and had asked about the status of Mr. Turner’s incarceration and location for deposition.

On February 6, 2025, at about 9:58 a.m., Sarena sent another message explaining scheduling constraints: February 24 is a Monday reserved for local motion hour and February 28 is a Friday Fayette motion hour. She indicated that February 26 or 27 would work for them, but they would need an earlier start time of 1:00 p.m.

Also on February 6, 2025, at 9:35 a.m., Krista Rice replied to all, noting a scheduling conflict for February 20 and asking if any of the dates February 24, 26, 27, or 28 would work instead.

Subsequently, at 10:25 a.m. (times shown in the thread), Krista Rice offered an alternative that Mr. Turner was not available until 3:30 p.m., and asked whether any of the dates March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20 would work.

Later that same day, at 10:28:37 a.m. Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle asked, “Is there a valid reason for his unavailability prior to 3:30 p.m.?” in reference to the proposed scheduling constraints.

The thread includes earlier exchanges as well, including a February 5 message chain where Sarena asked whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated and whether the deposition could be held at Rice Gumm’s office, and a note that the deposition would require coordination with the jail if incarceration remained a factor. The record also contains references to Filevine project emails for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021, indicating the case files and client records involved in the scheduling process.

There is also a dated entry from January 31, 2025, where Eric Rice sent a message to Bryce Koon and Daniel Gumm; however, the content of that correspondence is not fully shown in this record. The overall tenor of the exchanges is that the parties are working to find a workable deposition date for Mr. Turner, with The Whaley Law Firm preferring February 20 at 1:00 p.m. or later depending on availability, and Rice Gumm proposing various February and March options, all while trying to determine whether Mr. Turner would attend in person at the office or be detained/in jail.

In summary, this note documents the back-and-forth efforts of counsel and staff to schedule a deposition in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter, balancing the client’s availability, potential incarceration status, and existing court- and firm-initiated motion hours on specific dates in February and March 2025. The record ends with ongoing questions about the reasons for any unavailability before 3:30 p.m. and the need to confirm a suitable date and location.

episodes.natural_language:
This case note documents a February 2025 volley of scheduling emails between entities representing the parties in Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., regarding the deposition of a Mr. Turner in connection with the matter involving Juanita Nicole Downs, the client in the motor vehicle accident case Downs v. Nail (MVA date: 4/16/2021).

On January 31, 2025 at 9:55 AM, Eric S. Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC wrote to Bryce Koon and Daniel Gumm, with copies to Brian Stempien and the Filevine project addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021, as well as Sarena Tuttle. He indicated that he had not yet been able to speak with his client. He stated that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 PM on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20 if those dates would work.

On February 4, 2025 at 2:06 PM, Eric Rice again corresponded with Bryce, replying that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 PM on February 12 or 14, 18, 19, or 20 if those dates were workable.

On February 5, 2025 at 12:00 PM, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm responded that the only date that would work for their office would be February 20, 2025. She explained they have several mediations and depositions scheduled for the month and asked whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated or would attend the deposition at Rice & Gumm’s office; if incarcerated, they would need to check with the jail regarding processes and availability.

At about 1:50 PM on February 5, 2025, Eric Rice replied, “He’ll be here at my office,” indicating that Turner would attend at Rice & Gumm’s office rather than at a jail location.

Also on February 5, 2025 at 1:56 PM, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged the confirmation and asked Mr. Stempien whether February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm would work for him.

On February 5, 2025 at 1:56 PM, Sarena followed up with a separate message confirming that February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm was the date that works for their office, and reiterated the need to know whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated or would attend in their office, since if incarcerated they would need to coordinate with the jail.

On February 6, 2025 at 9:35 AM, Krista Rice responded to the group by noting a scheduling conflict for February 20 and asked whether any of the alternative dates—February 24, 26, 27, or 28—would work.

Later on February 6, 2025 at 9:58 AM, Sarena Tuttle replied that February 24 is a Monday (local motion hour) and February 28 is a Friday (Fayette motion hour). She stated that they were available on February 26 or 27 but required an earlier start time of 1:00 PM.

At about 10:25 AM on February 6, 2025, Krista Rice responded that Mr. Turner was not available until 3:30 PM and proposed new dates: March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20.

Finally, at 10:29 AM on February 6, 2025, Sarena Tuttle sent a reply asking whether any of the proposed dates would work or if additional dates were needed.

The initial email in the thread—dated February 6, 2025 at 16:20:49 +0000 from Krista Rice—summarized the ongoing exchange by asking for confirmation on whether any of the proposed dates would work or if Krista should provide additional options. The correspondence chain also confirms the participants and roles: Krista Rice (Firm Administrator for Rice Gumm, PLLC), Sarena M. Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm), with other participants including Eric Rice (Rice Gumm, PLLC) and Brian Stempien (involved in the matter), as well as the Filevine project addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021.

Key details preserved across the notes include:
- The case name and status: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., with client Juanita Nicole Downs related to a motor vehicle accident on 4/16/2021.
- The deposition planning for Mr. Turner, with the deposition location being potentially at Rice & Gumm, PLLC (Eric Rice’s office) unless Turner is incarcerated.
- The specific dates and times proposed and discussed: initial options of 3:30 PM on February 12, 14, 18, 19, or 20; then adjustments to February 20; consideration of February 24, 26, 27, or 28 with a preferred 1:00 PM start; and later consideration of March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20 with a 3:30 PM or other times as discussed.
- Scheduling constraints noted by the offices: local motion hour on February 24, Fayette motion hour on February 28, the need for an earlier start on February 26 or 27, and the requirement to confirm whether Turner would appear in person at the office or be incarcerated.
- The involved parties and their contact details as reflected in the email headers, including multiple participants and the Filevine project email addresses related to Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 4/16/2021.

In sum, this is a recorded exchange in early February 2025 among Rice Gumm, PLLC and The Whaley Law Firm, together with associated counsel, working to coordinate a deposition of Mr. Turner in the Adkins & Downs v Nail case, with a focus on determining an acceptable date, time, and location given Turner’s availability and the courts’ and offices’ scheduling constraints.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., the file titled Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021 concerns Juanita Nicole Downs (a motor vehicle accident claimant whose incident occurred on 04/16/2021) along with Destiny Adkins (also a 04/16/2021 MVA file). The deposition in question was for the defendant, Turner, and the parties were attempting to schedule it during normal business hours with enough time to conduct a proper deposition.

The scheduling dialogue unfolded in a series of emails exchanged between The Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm, PLLC, beginning on February 5, 2025. Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent the initial message to Eric Rice and Krista Rice, with copies to others including Brian Stempien and colleagues handling the Destiny Adkins MVA and Juanita Downs MVA matters via their Filevine project addresses. The subject of the thread was Re: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. In that first message, Sarena asked whether February 20, 2025 at 3:30 p.m. at Rice & Gumm would work for Mr. Stempien, expressing that she appreciated the confirmation and seeking a firm answer about the date and time.

Eric Rice replied later that day, stating that Mr. Turner would be at his office. In response, Sarena asked Mr. Stempien to confirm whether February 20, 2025 at 3:30 p.m. at Rice & Gumm work for him. Eric’s reply indicated that Turner would attend at Rice & Gumm’s office, and Sarena reiterated the request to confirm.

On February 6, 2025, Sarena followed up with Krista, asking whether there was a valid reason for Turner’s unavailability prior to 3:30 p.m. Krista initially noted that Turner was not available until 3:30 p.m. and asked whether any of several dates would work: March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20. Earlier in the day, Krista had informed the group that Turner was not available until 3:30 p.m. and proposed those dates, given a scheduling conflict for February 20, 2025.

Sarena responded that she needed to know Turner’s availability rather than the dates alone. She explained that the 24th of February is a Monday reserved for local motion hour and the 28th is a Friday reserved for Fayette motion hour, and that they were available on February 26 or February 27, but they required an earlier start time of 1:00 p.m. Krista acknowledged the scheduling constraints but reiterated the February 20 conflict and asked for confirmation of any of the proposed dates (February 24, 26, 27, or 28). Krista then proposed additional March dates (March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20) since Turner’s schedule appeared limited.

Sarena pressed back, noting that the 24th and 28th dates were constrained by motion-hour commitments and that they could accommodate February 26 or 27 if a 1:00 p.m. start could be arranged. She also asked if a valid reason existed for Turner’s unavailability before 3:30 p.m., given the expectation that the deposition occur during normal business hours and with sufficient duration. These exchanges included the standard confidentiality notices typical of communications with Rice Gumm, PLLC, and the messages carried the usual email signatures with contact information for the participants.

Over the course of the exchange, the participants referenced the deposition window for Turner and debated whether a 1:00 p.m. start would be feasible or if a later start (such as 3:30 p.m.) could be accommodated. The thread recorded a pattern of back-and-forth about available dates (late February into March) and explicit concern from the Whaley team that an hour and a half would not be enough time for a proper deposition, plus the need to schedule within regular business hours. The communications also documented that several emails included the Filevine Project email addresses for Destiny Adkins and Juanita Downs, reflecting their involvement in the related MVA matters.

In sum, the notes capture a multi-party effort in early February 2025 to schedule a deposition for Def Turner, with the core tension centered on start times and the allocation of several February and March dates around court motion hours (notably the 24th and 28th February) and the requirement for a 1:00 p.m. start to ensure a proper deposition within normal business hours. The exchanges included multiple signatories and attachments, including the standard confidentiality notices embedded in each Rice Gumm, PLLC email.

Case: Juanita Nicole Downs MVA, 4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. This narrative summarizes the email correspondence from February 5–6, 2025 concerning scheduling a deposition in the matter Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., in which Juanita Nicole Downs is the client in the motor vehicle accident (MVA) case dated 4-16-2021. The thread shows communications among the Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm, PLLC, with copies to other counsel, regarding whether and when to depose a person named Def Turner, and how to address the start time and duration of the deposition.

On February 5, 2025, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm emailed Eric S. Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC (and Krista Rice, the firm administrator, with others CC’d) to propose February 20, 2025 at 3:30 p.m. at Rice & Gumm as the deposition date and location for Def Turner. She referenced Mr. Stempien in her note and asked whether that date and time would work for him. The message includes the confidentiality notice typical of emails between counsel. In response, Eric Rice replied that “he’ll be here at my office,” indicating that Def Turner would attend the deposition at Rice Gumm’s office.

Later on February 5, Krista Rice followed up with a scheduling question, noting a conflict with February 20 and asking whether any of several alternative dates would work: February 24, 26, 27, or 28. This message also carries the confidentiality notice. The thread then shows a back-and-forth addressing Turner’s availability: Sarena asked whether there was a valid reason for his unavailability prior to 3:30 p.m., while Krista reiterated that Turner was not available until 3:30 and proposed additional dates in March: March 6, 12, 13, 19, or 20.

As this exchange continued, Sarena again pressed for a valid reason if the deposition could not start at 1:00 p.m. or sooner, emphasizing that the start time matters and that the client is obligated to appear for a deposition during normal business hours. Krista’s replies attempted to converge on workable dates, asking whether any of the proposed dates would be suitable or if more information was needed. The messages again note Turner’s restriction to a later start time, and the team considered multiple date options across late February and March.

Throughout the thread, the participants reference the same core issue: whether Def Turner can appear for a deposition starting at or before 1:00 p.m. on a weekday, and if not, whether a 3:30 p.m. start could be accommodated on the proposed dates. Eric Rice’s initial instruction suggested that a motion could be filed if needed and indicated a belief that the matter was not difficult to resolve, noting that there was no evidence Turner was driving and that Turner had already provided a sworn answer stating he was not driving, along with references to the listed insured and vehicle owner. He also suggested explaining why a 3:30 start could work for the 20th.

The chain shows the Whaley Law Firm’s calendar management for the deposition in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail case, with the deposition of Def Turner ultimately being coordinated around Turner’s stated availability and the parties’ preference for a deposition during normal business hours. The email headers reveal the involved parties and contact points: Eric S. Rice (Rice Gumm, PLLC), Krista Rice (Firm Administrator), Sarena M. Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm), and other recipients including Bryce Koon and Brian Stempien, with multiple copies and the standard confidentiality notices attached to every message. The chain also lists the respective firms’ contact details: Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243, and the Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville office, along with phone numbers and emails for the participants.

In sum, the notes reflect an active scheduling dispute over when Def Turner could be deposed in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter, with the opposing sides debating start times (1:00 p.m. or earlier versus a earliest permissible 3:30 p.m.), possible dates in February and March, and the strategic option of filing another motion to compel if a reasonable start time could not be agreed upon. The discussion consistently emphasizes that the deposition should occur during normal business hours and that a deposition lasting about one and a half hours is deemed insufficient if the start time cannot be moved earlier. The correspondence is dated February 5–6, 2025, and contains the typical confidentiality notices found in all communications among counsel.
