Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021
Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

This note summarizes a sequence of email communications about scheduling a deposition in the matter Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., concerning the client Juanita Nicole Downs in a motor vehicle collision that occurred on 4/16/2021.

On February 5, 2025, at 1:56 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent a message to Eric Rice, Bryce Koon, Daniel Gumm, Brian Stempien, and related Filevine project addresses for the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter. She thanked Mr. Stempien for some prior confirmation and asked whether February 20, 2025 at 3:30 PM at Rice & Gumm would work for him. The email references “Mr. Stempien” and notes the inquiry was in the context of the deposition scheduling. The message was sent with standard confidentiality language and included the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and the new email address for Sarena Tuttle.

Earlier in the day, Krista Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC had asked for guidance on whether the proposed dates would work or if additional information was needed. Krista indicated a scheduling conflict for 2/20 and proposed alternative dates: 2/24, 2/26, 2/27, or 2/28.

Sarena responded later that morning (9:58 AM) with a question: was there a valid reason for the unavailability prior to 3:30 PM? She asked this in the context of the request to depose the deponent at times other than 1:00 PM, emphasizing that the dates were not the sole issue and that the start time mattered.

Krista replied at 10:25 AM, explaining that Mr. Turner was not available until 3:30 PM and asking whether any of the following dates would work: 3/6, 3/12, 3/13, 3/19, or 3/20. Krista included her standard firm signature block for Rice Gumm, PLLC.

Sarena pushed back again at 10:29 AM, asking whether there was a valid reason for the unavailability before 3:30 PM. In response, Krista later proposed further options and asked for confirmation on which dates would work, citing that 2/20 had a conflict and reiterating the 1:00 PM start preference if possible.

At 11:20 AM (and again at 11:27 AM), Krista confirmed that the proposed dates were to be considered or requested additional information, while Sarena insisted that the reason for the later start time be provided and reiterated that the start time was the core issue. She stated that the client is obligated to appear for a deposition during normal business hours and that an hour-and-a-half would not be sufficient to conduct a proper deposition. She warned that without a valid reason why Def Turner could not appear at 1:00 PM or sooner, the opposing side could deem him uncooperative and pursue another motion to compel. These messages were sent with the Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality language.

In the thread, Krista had previously outlined available dates when she could confirm scheduling, noting the presence of a local motion hour on 2/24 (a Monday) and Fayette motion hour on 2/28 (a Friday), and stating that they were available on 2/26 or 2/27 but required an earlier start time of 1:00 PM. She listed dates including 2/24, 2/26, 2/27, and 2/28, and then later noted that 2/20 was unavailable due to a scheduling conflict.

The exchange also contained standard agency notices typical of attorney communications, including the formatting and disclaimers for Privileged and Confidential Information and the IRS Circular 230 warning regarding tax advice, embedded in the messages from Stempien and the various firm signatures.

Overall, the thread reflects a persistent effort to schedule the deposition in Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., with ongoing disputes over the acceptable start time (preferably 1:00 PM) and a series of proposed dates in February and March 2025, while ensuring compliance with normal business hours and addressing the scheduling constraints of Mr. Turner. The case note consistently references the client, Juanita Nicole Downs, and the underlying MVA matter dated 4/16/2021.

In early February 2025, counsel from multiple firms were attempting to schedule a deposition in this matter. On February 6, 2025, at 4:33 p.m. UTC, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC sent an email regarding the scheduling and stated, “We should be able to make any day work, so please just let me know once you guys hammer out the date.” His message included his firm’s contact information: Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1 (866) 431-3599; Email: bstempien@thattorneys.com; Web: http://www.thslaw.co. The email carried the customary privileged and confidential disclaimer, noting that the information was attorney-privileged and confidential, intended only for the named recipient; it warned that dissemination or copying was prohibited if you were not the intended recipient, and urged the reader to contact the sender and delete the message if received in error. It also stated that no attorney-client relationship is established by sending or receiving e-mails with the firm, and it included the IRS Circular 230 tax disclosure warning about potential tax penalties in relation to tax advice.

Earlier that same week, Krista Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC replied on February 6, 2025 at 9:35 a.m. to Sarena Rice’s email, and to others, explaining that there was a scheduling conflict for February 20 and asking whether any of the dates February 24, 26, 27, or 28 would work. Krista’s message included her firm’s contact details: 502-290-1075; admin@ricegummlaw.com; Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; www.ricegummlaw.com; and the firm’s logo.

The thread also shows earlier communications from The Whaley Law Firm. On February 5, 2025, at 1:56 p.m., Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to Eric Rice and CC’d Bryce Koon, Daniel Gumm, Brian Stempien, and Filevine project addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 04/16/2021. The subject was the same matter. Sarena asked, “Thank you so much for the confirmation. Mr. Stempien, does February 20, 2025 at 3:30p at Rice & Gumm, work for you?” Her signature block provided her title and firm details: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address).

In response on February 5, 2025 at 1:50 p.m., Eric Rice, a partner at Rice Gumm, replied, “He’ll be here at my office.” Eric’s contact details are shown as: 502-290-1075; eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com; Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; www.ricegummlaw.com.

Earlier still, on February 4, 2025, at 2:06 p.m., Eric Rice wrote to Bryce that Mr. Turner could be available at 3:30 p.m. on February 12 or 14, 18, 19, or 20 if those dates would work. He signed as Eric S. Rice, Partner, with the same Rice Gumm contact details and confidentiality notice.

On February 4, 2025 at 1:56 p.m.—or around that time, as reflected in the chain—the message from Sarena Tuttle captured a key response from the Whaley team: “The only one of those dates that works for our office would be February 20th. We have several Mediations & Depositions already scheduled for this month. Is/will your client, Mr. Turner, still be incarcerated or will this deposition take place at your office? If your client is still incarcerated, we will need to check with the Jail for their process & availability.” Sarena’s contact information and Whaley Law Firm details followed.

Earlier still, on February 5, 2025 at 12:00 p.m., Sarena again wrote to Eric Rice, restating that February 20th was the only date that worked for their office, and reiterating the need to know whether Mr. Turner would be incarcerated or available for a deposition at the office, noting the jail’s process and availability if incarceration continued.

On January 31, 2025 at 9:55 a.m., Eric Rice had told Bryce (with others copied) that he had not yet been able to speak with his client. His message began, “Bello Bryce, I haven’t been able to speak with my client as of yet,” and was sent from Eric S. Rice, Partner, Rice Gumm, PLLC, with the firm’s address and website. The thread then shows further scheduling discussions emerging in February.

In summary, the email chain shows a coordinated effort among counsel at Rice Gumm, The Whaley Law Firm, and Travis Herbert & Stempien to schedule a deposition for Mr. Turner in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al. matter. The proposed target date was February 20, 2025 at 3:30 p.m. at Rice & Gumm’s offices, contingent on Mr. Turner’s availability and whether he would be incarcerated or could attend at the office. If the February 20 slot could not be used, Krista Rice proposed alternatives for February 24, 26, 27, or 28, due to a scheduling conflict for February 20. Brian Stempien stated that they should be able to accommodate any day once a date was hammered out. The thread cites Filevine project email addresses for Destiny Adkins MVA 04/16/2021 and Juanita Nicole Downs MVA 04/16/2021, and includes the standard confidentiality and privilege notices, along with the No Attorney-Client Relationship disclaimer and the IRS Circular 230 tax-advice disclosure.

The file header shows the case reference and participant names, and the most recent outreach occurred on March 4, 2025, when Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC emailed colleagues to ask, “Did you guys get a date for this depo?” The email was sent from Stempien to Eric S. Rice (Rice Gumm, PLLC), Sarena Tuttle (The Whaley Law Firm), and Krista Rice (admin at Rice Gumm, PLLC), with a copy to Bryce at Whaley Law Firm. Stempien’s full contact details were included in his signature, along with a note indicating the message was Privileged and Confidential, and the standard attorney-privilege disclaimers. The firm’s address is the Jefferson Marders Building, 11507 Main Street, Middletown Historic District, Louisville, KY 40243; office phone 502-245-7474; fax 502-245-7025; toll-free 1-866-431-3599; email bstempien@thattorneys.com; website www.thslaw.co.

The February 6, 2025 exchanges lay out a scheduling push with several participants: Krista Rice (Firm Administrator, Rice Gumm, PLLC, Louisville, KY), Sarena M. Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm), Eric Rice (Partner, Rice Gumm, PLLC), Bryce (Whaley Law Firm), and Brian Stempien (Travis Herbert & Stempien). The central issue was locating a deposition time for the deponent, referred to as Def Turner, in a way that satisfies all sides given Turner’s availability and the court-imposed motion-hour constraints.

First, on February 6, 2025 at 9:35 a.m., Krista Rice noted that there was a scheduling conflict for February 20 and asked whether any of the proposed dates—February 24, 26, 27, or 28—would work, inviting input from the team. In response, at 9:58 a.m., Sarena Tuttle explained that February 24 is a Monday reserved for local motion hour and February 28 is a Fayette motion hour, and that they were available on February 26 or 27, but required an earlier start time of 1:00 p.m. She supplied the same availability details with her signature and NEW email address.

Shortly thereafter, at 10:25 a.m., Sarena followed up with a different set of proposed dates because Mr. Turner would not be available until 3:30 p.m. She asked whether any of the dates 3/6, 3/12, 3/13, 3/19, or 3/20 would work. Krista responded at 10:29 a.m. asking if there was a valid reason for Turner’s unavailability prior to 3:30 p.m. and emphasizing that the start time was the issue, since an hour and a half is not sufficient to conduct a proper deposition; she noted that Turner’s unavailability before 3:30 p.m. could lead to a motion to compel if no valid justification was provided.

Sarena replied at 11:27 a.m., reiterating the concern about the start time rather than the dates themselves, stating that Turner would be unavailable before 3:30 and that 1:00 p.m. starts and a 1.5-hour deposition were not adequate. She warned that Turner could be deemed uncooperative and that another motion to compel might be filed if a valid reason for the limited availability was not provided. Her message carried the Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice and reiterated her contact details.

At 11:30 a.m., Eric Rice weighed in, advising that Bryce could file a motion and that counsel could explain to the judge that there was no evidence Turner was driving and that Turner had already provided a sworn statement indicating he was not driving, along with the listed insured and vehicle owner. Eric suggested it would be appropriate to explain why a 3:30 start would work for the 20th, and stated that this was not a difficult issue. He signed with his title, office details, and firm information, and included the confidentiality notice.

The chain of messages also references earlier scheduling options, including February 20 as a conflict, with contemplation of February 24, 26, 27, or 28 as possible windows, and later consideration of March dates (3/6, 3/12, 3/13, 3/19, 3/20) when Turner would be available at 3:30 p.m. The correspondence notes that the 24th is a Monday reserved for local motion hour and the 28th is a Friday Fayette motion hour, thus impacting the feasibility of those dates; the Whaley team suggested 26th or 27th as possibilities with a 1:00 p.m. start, while Rice Gumm proposed later March dates with Turner available after 3:30.

This lengthy email thread thus captures the scheduling impasse: Turner’s unavailability before 3:30 p.m. on certain days, the need for a start time of 1:00 p.m. or later, the desire to avoid local and Fayette motion-hour days, and the willingness of counsel to pursue relief via a motion to compel if a reasonable, compliant deposition time could not be agreed upon. The March 4, 2025 message from Brian Stempien serves as a follow-up prompting confirmation of a deposition date.

In sum, the parties attempted to resolve when and how to depose Def Turner in Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., balancing Turner’s availability, the required deposition duration of at least 1 hour and 30 minutes, and the court’s motion-hour constraints, while maintaining confidentiality and preserving attorney-client communications throughout. Relevant contact details repeated across signatures include:

- Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC: Brian D. Stempien, Jeffrey M. … (address provided in signature), Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1 (866) 431-3599; bstempien@thattorneys.com; Web: http://www.thslaw.co
- Rice Gumm, PLLC: Eric S. Rice (512-290-1075 listed in signature), 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; eric.rice@ricegummlaw.com; www.ricegummlaw.com
- Krista Rice (Firm Administrator): admin@ricegummlaw.com; 502-290-1075; Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243
- The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle): 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com

Please note that the emails included standard confidentiality notices, stated that there is no attorney-client relationship created by sending or receiving the email, and included Circular 230 tax-disclosure language where applicable.

Client: Juanita Nicole Downs

This notes pertain to the matter Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., and document a deposition-scheduling dialogue among counsel for the parties. The deposition in question concerns a defendant identified as Turner and is part of the Adkins & Downs v. Nail case.

In the email thread dated February 6, 2025, Krista Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC informed the opposing side that Mr. Turner is not available until 3:30 p.m. She asked whether any of the proposed dates would work: March 6, March 12, March 13, March 19, or March 20. A few minutes later, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm asked whether there was a valid reason for Turner’s unavailability prior to 3:30 p.m. She stated that the issue was not the dates themselves but the start time.

Krista Rice replied later that morning, asking to know whether any of the proposed dates could work or whether additional information was needed. In response, Sarena Tuttle asserted that the start time was the critical issue: Turner’s deposition should occur during normal business hours, and one hour and a half is not sufficient to conduct a proper deposition. She warned that, without a valid reason why Turner could not appear at 1:00 p.m. or earlier, Turner could be deemed uncooperative and a motion to compel might be filed.

Eric Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC then joined the thread, advising that Bryce could file a motion and that they could explain to the judge that there is no evidence Turner was driving and that Turner had already provided sworn testimony stating he was not driving, alongside the listed insured and vehicle owner. He also suggested explaining why 3:30 p.m. could work for the 20th, stating, “This is not difficult.”

The thread then shows continuing exchanges within the same day, including the standard confidentiality and attorney-privilege disclosures typical of these communications.

On March 4, 2025 at approximately 1:38 PM, Brian D. Stempien of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC asked, “Did you guys get a date for this depo?” In reply, Sarena Tuttle, the Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, said, “Good afternoon Mr. Stempien, Unfortunately, no. This deposition has not yet been scheduled. Bryce is in a deposition out of town today but I will follow up with him upon his return later this afternoon.” She signed as before, noting her contact information and new email address.

The underlying context is that the parties are attempting to schedule the deposition of Turner in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail case, with the defense proposing 3:30 p.m. starts and a set of potential dates (3/6, 3/12, 3/13, 3/19, 3/20). The plaintiff’s side has insisted the deposition occur earlier in the day or at a time that would allow a longer, properly conducted deposition, and there has been discussion of motions to compel if a reasonable scheduling arrangement cannot be reached. As of March 4, 2025, no date for the deposition had been set, and Bryce was temporarily unavailable due to being in another deposition out of town.

>> *Sent:* Thursday, February 6, 2025 10:29 AM
>> *To:* Krista Rice 
>> *Cc:* Eric Rice ; bryce@whaleylawfirm.com;
>> Brian Stempien 
>> *Subject:* Re: Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al.
>>
>>
>>
>> Is there a valid reason for his unavailability prior to 3:30p?
>>
>>
>>
>
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Juanita-Nicole-Downs-MVA-4-16-2021. Client: Juanita Nicole Downs. In the matter captioned Adkins & Downs v. Nail, et al., the Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm PLLC were coordinating regarding the deposition of Demetrius Turner. On March 5, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent counsel a notice to take the deposition of Demetrius Turner. The deposition was scheduled for April 17, 2025 at 12:00 p.m. at Turner’s attorney’s office, Rice Gumm PLLC. The notice was attached, and the email invited any questions and offered to discuss them further. The message was addressed to Brian Stempien and CC’d to Eric Rice, Krista Rice, and Bryce from Whaley Law Firm. The Whaley email included Sarena’s contact information and noted a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville office is located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line (502) 357-9971 and office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104; the email signature also advised that the address contains the new contact email.

Earlier in the chain, on March 4, 2025, at about 1:40 p.m. (the exact minute is recorded as 1:40?PM), Sarena Tuttle wrote to Mr. Stempien: unfortunately, the deposition had not yet been scheduled. Bryce was in a deposition out of town that day, but she would follow up with him upon his return later that afternoon. Her message reiterated her role and provided the same office details and new email address.

In response, at around 1:38 p.m. on March 4, 2025, Brian Stempien asked, “Did you guys get a date for this depo? Thank You,” and signed as part of Travis Herbert & Stempien, PLLC, with the firm’s address in Louisville and standard contact details (Office: (502) 245-7474; Fax: (502) 245-7025; Toll Free: 1-866-431-3599; Email: bstempien@thattorneys.com; Web: http://www.thslaw.co). The chain includes the typical attorney-client confidentiality and privilege notices that accompany these communications.

Throughout this same February–March period, an earlier chain (starting February 6, 2025) involved Eric S. Rice of Rice Gumm, PLLC, communicating with Sarena Tuttle, Krista Rice, Bryce, and Brian Stempien. In Eric Rice’s February 6, 2025 message, he suggested that Bryce could file a motion and explained that there was no evidence Demetrius Turner was driving and that Turner had already provided sworn testimony stating he was not driving, along with the listed insured and vehicle owner. He also noted the possibility of explaining why 3:30 p.m. had been proposed for the 20th (February 20, 2025). The message is embedded with Rice Gumm’s standard confidentiality and privilege notices and includes the firm’s contact information: Rice Gumm, PLLC, 12804 Townepark Way, Ste. 200, Louisville, KY 40243; website www.ricegummlaw.com.

Earlier still, on February 6, 2025, Sarena Tuttle responded to Krista Rice with a query: “Care to provide the reason?” She indicated that the dates were not the issue; the start time was. She emphasized that the client is obligated to provide his deposition during normal business hours and that an hour and a half is not sufficient to conduct a proper deposition. She warned that without a valid reason why Demetrius Turner was unavailable before 1:00 p.m. or sooner, he could be considered uncooperative and that they would be forced to file another motion to compel.

In a contemporaneous thread, Krista Rice (Firm Administrator for Rice Gumm, PLLC) replied on February 6, 2025, asking if any of the proposed dates would work or if additional options were needed. Her message included her contact information: 502-290-1075 and admin@ricegummlaw.com, along with Rice Gumm’s Louisville address and website. The chain also contains the standard confidentiality notices found in these exchanges.

The February 6, 2025 communications included a response from Sarena Tuttle later that morning (or around 11:27 a.m.), reaffirming that the issue was the start time rather than the dates and reiterating the expectation that Turner appear within normal business hours for a deposition lasting approximately 1.5 hours. She again cautioned that Turner’s unavailability before 1:00 p.m. without a valid reason could lead to a motion to compel, consistent with their procedural posture in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail matter.

In short, the notes document a pending deposition notice for Demetrius Turner scheduled for April 17, 2025 at 12:00 p.m. at Rice Gumm PLLC, issued March 5, 2025 by The Whaley Law Firm on behalf of Juanita Nicole Downs in the Adkins & Downs v. Nail dispute. They also reveal a back-and-forth in early February and early March 2025 about scheduling, preferred start times (with particular focus on 1:00 p.m., 3:30 p.m., and the potential 3:30 start for February 20, 2025), the assertion that Turner’s deposition should occur during normal business hours, the possibility of filing motions to compel if Turner's unavailability could not be justified, and the ongoing coordination between The Whaley Law Firm and Rice Gumm PLLC, including multiple standard confidentiality and privilege notices and the clients’ and counsel’s contact details.
